was here with a group , we were given ice cold bread and butter it took at least 10 mins to get warm bread and the place was not crowded. the waiter asked if we wanted a checks split which was nice considering how a lot of places give you a hard time over stuff like that. i had the lemonhead martini it was a pretty standard lemon drop martini it was good but i expected something a little more candy like the but it had a great kick to it so i was cool with it. had the crab cake appetizer it was full of lump crab meat and was served with a spicy sauce, the sauce was good but it was a little to hot. i ordered the meatloaf and mashed potatoes it was huge 3 nice size pieces with mashed potatoes. the meat loaf was good the potatoes were horrible i even tried to put the yummy mushroom sauce on them and they were still bad. the garlic spinach was ok, the crab legs were really good. i had the grapehead martini and that one was really good, tasted just like a grapehead with a great kick, had the huge slice of chocolate cake that i will be eating for the next week really not a big steak eater so this place is not high on my list to come back to

Food was ok at best which frankly is not good enough considering the prices.  The problems with my visit were as follows: 1. Made a reservation yet still had to wait 45 minutes for a table. 2. There is no waiting area to speak of, so the entryway serves the purpose.  This is inconvenient because patrons are not able to reach the hostess stand and also because those in the dining room are unable to reach the stairs to visit the restroom without pushing and shoving through.  3. They crammed 12 people around a table made for a maximum of 10. 4. Because we were crammed, each time a server filled a glass or placed a glass or plate (and thus retrieved a plate) in front of you, you get a lot of armpit on your shoulder and to escape you must invade the personal space of the people next to you.   5. Water was not refilled in a timely manner. 6. There were three checks at the table and the server was unable to get the checks straight. 7. Because tables are crammed in the space, there is no room to walk so each time someone passes, you get an ass to the shoulder, head, or back or their thigh knocks something off your table.   Save your money, go somewhere cheaper and have a better more comfortable experience.

Now this was an interesting experience...  The name, the fame, the pizzazz, the celebrities that have eaten here and a one time past experience prompted me to take my guest to this place for their birthday. With no reservations on a weekend night we were surprisingly ushered to a table within 25 minutes to be seated. The waiter was too proud of his huge steak samples which he displayed in front of us while talking at the speed of light about the form of cut it was etc etc....  I gave it a 3 star because of the quality of the food we received VS the hindsight notion of eating at one of the fanciest yet tastiest steak houses in Chi town.  Utter disappointment with the flavor and the cooking consistency of the meat served. Their Medium Rare was more like a Medium burnt in all honesty.  I will consider another steakhouse the next time around to take my steak loving friend whose opinion I deeply care about and respect. :-)
Probably my favorite steak in the city. Other great food too. Steak sandwich for lunch is good. Lobster bisque nice.

Well, this review is fairly late, but whatevs.  So I'm getting off of work, and everyone is wondering where to have dinner.  Word on the street is that Gibson's 20th Anniversary special was also good for the night before.  So we mosey on up to the bar, and order some grub.  $20 for a Bone-In Rib Eye.  $1 for a gynormous double baked potato.  Oh the food was amazing!  I would have even been fine paying full price!  Service was impeccable, as I would have expected no less.  This is a great classic steak house.  Meat, Taters and Vino, Oh MY!

I was taken here last night for my 19th *wink* birthday.  I had the smaller NY strip, and a pear martini. The service was beyond excellent.  I really enjoyed my steak and was rather sad as that I didn't get to have a sweet because I was already stuffed from my appetizer at the Signature Lounge (tourist/birthday double duty). I will say that the steak did seem a little bit "tough"-  not sure if it was the steak or the steak knife.  The crowd is very different than what I am used to but that never holds me back from getting a nom on when I need it. Besides, a little bit of rock and roll never hurt anyone, did it? I would definitely recommend and hope to come again- when my tummy is bigger!

While I have eaten at the restaurant several times I'm going to write about going here for happy hour. This has been a favorite place to go for after work drinks and food.  Get here before 7 or else the bar area gets very crowded and you won't find a table.  The drinks do start to add up but the service is great and the martini's are awesome.  Although not on the menu, you can get the fillet sliders with fries - perfect happy hour food to snack on.  100% recommended and reasonably priced for a quick dinner.  The past few times I've been here we drank for several hours.  Atmosphere is perfect for an after work drinking extravaganza on Thursdays or Fridays.

I struggle with only a four if there was only a half system!  It is as good a steak and potato place as I've ever been in or ever really need. I can't say enough about the manager Marc and how we felt the overall experience was amazingly good. First Creme Brulee I ordered I almost couldn't finish because of its size.  It will just have to be enough that I will always be back to feast when I'm inside 50 miles.  Thanks again,
Does this place really need another review??  Get the bone in ribeye, rare. Also, get the twice baked potato, and share the potato with your date.  The ribeye is the best steak I've ever had.

I've gone to many Steakhouses throughout the US however Gibson's is my number 1 and I believe it is one of the best Steakhouses in the whole country.  Service is top of the line and everyone in our table enjoyed their dish.  Great wine list, great side selection and of course great desserts.  Do plan your visit and reserve with time since it is always full.  A must when your in Chicago.

This place makes you feel like cattle while you are eating cattle. They shuffle you in and out like you're simply components on an assembly line in a severely cramped dining room that's very uncomfortable. Supposedly they spoil their customers blindly but that's not how I felt during the process, especially if the waitstaff forgets your cocktail order twice. The steaks are certainly tasty but I would not consider the obnoxious wait nor the terrible service worth it in the first place.

Very classy 'old school' restaurant...Class A service (your needs will be catered to).  The steak was wonderful, cooked to perfection and my liking.  I also had their chickent and it was wonderful as well.  Can't go wrong with a nice large salad, mashed potatoes and green beans.  I love a great steak and you will surely get one at Gibson's.

This place is really classy with an old school vibe, a really kewl steak house. The staff was very friendly, especially our waiter George. This guy gets props for:  knowing what a Vesper martini is, being well versed with the various cuts of steak, helpful with alternative entrees and attentive never intrusive. The food was amazing! My New York strip was served nice and bloody (med. rare). Damn, these portions are huge! My date had bass and that was a buttery delight. Had to pass on dessert  because they were equally impressive in proportions! Great experience and food!

Love the atmosphere here... still a little old-school, but cool enough to enjoy on the weekend. We went to a wedding cocktail event here and had the upstairs area. Awesome appetizers and drinks!  We went back before going home to Boston and sat at the bar for a burger and drinks - again, great food & service! Would have loved to have a nice sit-down dinner here - the menu looked great.

Came here for one of my Birthday dinners during my birthday weekend....hopefully my guest won't see this review as he knows my love for steak and wanted to take me to the best steak place in Chicago in his opinion.  But I was just not impressed....we came on a Friday night around 7:30 without reservations.  We hung out at the bar and shockingly were called for a table in 20-25 mins.  The dining area was rather noisy and the waiter was talking WAY too fast and more focused on his gigantic raw steaks he was holding....I love my steak but I just want something that I can eat in one sitting and that won't give me a heart attack the next day.  I opted for the petite filet medium and a salad....salad was a huge let down.  I know its just the dinner salad but come one, iceberg lettuce with at least two chunks of the steam it in, 1 slice of cucumber and 2 cherry tomatoes??  Um olive garden has them way beat there.  And once I got my steak it was too charred on the outside and too rare on the inside....just not impressed....I think I have had better steak, and for those of you reading please don't judge me, at Outback steakhouse....it was just nothing special other then the company I was with!

Beautiful afternoon or evening in Chicago? Try your luck and grab a table outside. It's located on the best street corner in Chicago. Especially conducive if you've just spent the afternoon shopping on the nearby Michigan Ave.

I never, ever go to Chicago without hitting Gibson's.  I normally travel on business, so I sit at the bar.  The bartenders are professional, quick witted, and informative.  The wine list is great, and the food is what you expect from a traditional steakhouse.  The atmosphere is always exciting and the customers friendly.   It is what you look for in an established steakhouse.  It's hard to be on top and stay there, they have figured out how.   Can't wait to get back.

Well, well, well, yet another one of my favorites that I haven't reviewed. Shame on me.  Gibson's is, hands-down, the best steak place in Chicago. Sorry to those whose taste buds are not sufficient enough to agree. ;) Love you anyway.  The steaks are so perfectly seasoned and cooked every time and I wouldn't change a thing... that's saying something b/c nothing is perfect in my world.  The ambiance is so old school Chicago, you can smell the money made in some of the booths and tables. Did I just drink out of the same wine glass as some big wig who made a billion dollar deal? It could happen...  Gibson's I love you and while I might try others to confirm, I always have the same conclusion: no one is better than you.

The food is above average, but for the amount of money that they charge, it's totally overrated.  The steaks are charred to infused the flavor of the steak, however, the only thing I taste from my $50+ steak is the char.  Their shrimp cocktails are amazing, but at $3 per shrimp... it better be.

Gibson's is like a supper club on steroids! You order your meat and side separately (which you pay dearly for). I ordered the prime rib, which was literally bigger than my head.. The poor servers who have to lug around the trays with the sample meat platter must work out! Later, my friends insisted on ordering dessert- now a word of warning...any dessert that needs a special knife to cut it is too big!! It took four of us to make a dent in the sinfully rich "meaning of life." Now it seems like I'm complaining- I'm not.. The food is to die for- but you won't eat for a week afterwards-- just saying..  I would also have to say that when I was eating there I kept thinking that Gibson's is a perfect example of our glutenous, materialistic, greed filled American society (i.e. ordering portions way over our limit because we could.. expensive prices..etc.etc.).. weird right?

If you are a bartender don't you expect that on a Friday night at midnight (Sept. 24) you will probably get some "Relaxed" clientele? The 2 guys working the bar in this place are just plain nasty & mean. If you don't like people, or you don't like people who drink then maybe go work somewhere else.

I wouldn't choose to go back. Perhaps if the experience I had didn't mean waiting over our reservation time, waiting forever for our waiter who was obviously too busy, and eating food that tasted like it could be generic (no joke, my potatoes tasted like Betty Crocker from a box), I'd go back. I ordered fish at a steakhouse. Maybe that was my mistake? My plank fish (should've known it would suck since it was just under $20) was placed on a plank AFTER cooking and I was expecting a plank fish taste. I mentioned the terrible mashed potatoes already. I do have to say, though, the portions were quite large. Good thing considering the crazy prices.  My husband and friends liked their steaks, but I didn't hear favorable moaning or anything. My club soda was awesome.  With so many great restaurants in Chicago I have yet to try, there is no way I'd drive all the way out from the 'burbs to eat here again-- especially since there is one that I'm sure is equally "meh" quality in Oakbrook. Nights you wished you would've just gone to Chipotle. More pertinent info: Valet is $12 and I thought that was a great price for a restaurant on Rush.
1 word...amazing!! best food, great atmosphere and great great service!!!! nothing else to say! you've got to go!!!
I can't wait for my anniversary every year to go there!  My favorite steak place in town, including my favorite upbeat environment.

Wow, best steak hands-down.  The Chicago cut is a must.  If you go to Gibson's you have to get this cut and work your way from there.  It's packed with flavor and just melts in your mouth (we got it as a medium rare).  Since everything was so freaking huge, you could split everything with another person -- we split the steak, same as the sides and the dessert and was still ridiculously full at the end of it. Not too sure about the bread -- it's pretty good, but I think I like Morton's better.  The soup was mushroom soup for the weekend which was very rich and not overwhelming -- great balance!   If you're going for signature dishes at Gibson's, then you gotta get the Turtle Pie dessert.  It's vanilla ice cream+chocolate+macademia nuts all arranged together and the size of a basketball.  Be prepared. Service was AMAZING -- we fell in love with our servers, as they all knew what they were doing and helped create the atmosphere. Great experience, and will definitely need to come here again!

Everything we come to Chicago we must come to Gibsons.  Why?  It is a treat to be urban chaos.  Gibson is located in the Gold Coast on the RUSH.  It is cool vibrant restaurant. It is all steakhouse feel!  There is no trendy atmosphere to it.  The food was spectacular.  However, for a 9:30 reservation, we still had to wait 45 minutes in a super crowded bar.  The bar had stools and tables, but they are reserved so that leaves the bar counter or the piano. Great place to people watch if you can turn your head.  You are literally pressed up against someone. I would order some drinks, but it was just too crowded.  The crowd is your usual uptight Gold Coast crowd. The cool thing is that the men do dress up with coats and suits (maybe help from the Midwest wives) unlike the OC when dressing up for men is the True Religion jeans, boots with the monarch logo, and an Affliction T-Shirt.    The food is great, the chocolate cake serves a small army so be warned.  The house seasoning they used is excellent.  It is a cool place to be seen if you want that chaotic city feel.  I do once in awhile.  My bone in fillet was off the hook!  The side salad is plain, nothing fancy.  The soup was ordinary, but again, the steak was off the hook.   This place is way crowded.  I don't go to the Chi much, but every time it is the same super overflowing crowd.

Service was great, but that's where it ended.  I had a small fillet - no flavor at all.  I ordered medium rare - it came nice & pink in the middle, but the outside was hard and crusty.  I've had better steaks at TGI Friday's for a fourth the price. Soup - Beef & Barley - tasted like Campbell's Soup. Mixed vegetable side - okay, but why not cut the broccoli up a little rather than cooking almost an entire head at once & making the guest cut it up to serve it? There was one bright spot at the end of the meal - desert.  We had an Apple Turnover that was extremely good. Overall, not a place I would ever return.  For the $60 it cost me, not worth it.

Wow this review needed to wait until a not-so-hungry day to write. The thought of that Chicago cut makes me drool. It's intensively good. The size is HUGE! 20 oz chicago cut for 42 bucks is really quite quite reasonable. The spicy lobster platter appetizer was just OMG TOTALLY ROCKING AMAZING. Drinks at this place is just outstanding - Lemon drop, pear martini etc  It's a crowded place. We came here on a Wednesday night and this place is still FILLED with people. Awesome for BIG groups. We had 25 people in our group, seated in 3 different tables, everyone had an AWESOME TIME! Lovely evening. Thanks!

This is a great steak house, the portions are large enough to feed a small Ethiopian village and are fairly priced based on the zip code and what you get.  The steak was prepared to perfection and the sides were large but nothing special.  I thought the service was well above average however they have way too many tables for the size of the restaurant, creating a loud and crowded atmosphere, requiring you to yell across the table- contributing to the volume.

I had high hopes for this place, but unfortunately I found my steak and my date's salmon to be quite bland.  The atmosphere was nice and classy, and they do have big portions, but we both expected better food for the price  :(

Here in town on a business trip and taken to Gibson's as part of a large group. We were escorted upstairs to a private room and provided all the necessary bartenders and wait staff.  They did a great job keeping up with everyone's needs. Called to dinner, the staff quickly and efficiently took our food and drink orders.  The food came timely and prepared as well as can be expected with this size of a group. As can be expected, the desserts were a little over-the-top but good nonetheless. Cannot complain about the atmosphere, decor, service or quality of food.  The only reason not rated higher is because there is nothing to make Gibson's stand out, i.e., it has the same dark wood paneling, the same steaks and potatoes, celebrity photos adorning the walls, white coated service staff, etc. that most all steak houses possess.

Excellent restaurant across from Viagra Park. This restaurant had very good food and the most excellent service I have ever had. The server we had was friendly, attentive and went above and beyond. The chopped steak and philly sandwich was very good. The patio seating area was fantastic and provided great views of 90 year old men and their 21 year old trophies having their Ferraris valeted away. Exc - Service, patio Good - Food Ave - None Poor - None
Delicious! Love the steaks! Fries! Mashed potatoes! Annnnd MARTINIS! The honey tangerine and pomegrante is a must! The service is wonderful. Overall, I would fly back to Chi-town just for Gibs! =)

The bar is pretty crowded on weekend nights. Mostly with tourists who stay at the Sutton House. Decent late night menu. The truffle oil fries and sandwiches are very good. A decent mojito is made here.
This is one of my favorite restaurants, the portions are generous and the staff is excellent!  I have been going for years I have always left full and a smile on my face.  Works for me!

I almost feel like a traitor to my hometown...but really, it's not THAT impressive here.  Wait rewind - if we're talking cool, awesome Chicago vibe and feel and in a rockin neighborhood with celebrity sightings...then HELL YES!  5 stars, baby!  It is a great place to see and be seen. But I came to eat.  And my filet wasn't all that.  Both times.  Though, the apps and sides were pretty damn tasty a few times I came.  BUT i think one time, my calamari came from Hugo's - maybe cuz it was late...not sure...maybe that time shouldn't count as I had multiple martinis.... Alas, come here to drink and have appys and chill.  I wouldn't come here for full blown dinner....too pricey for what you get.  Oh, and get this, I have always been treated here...so even free, you know I'm keepin it real.  But that doesn't mean I won't be back.

My absolute favorite resto in Chicago, hands down. Some of you will gasp disgustingly & disagree & never read my reviews again, but I don't care, get over it. This is happening.  Here's why: it's 100%, total package, completely Chicago in atmosphere, in attitude, in food (quality & quantity), in kitch, in celebs and tourists and locals and cognoscenti and dbags alike.  When you think Midwest, think Homeland for Carnivores, think just-the-basics-done-fabulously meat & potatoes. Think land of all things gluttonous, and waiters ('cause yeah, they're all dudes) who've been there for decades and know what the hell they're doing at all times. Think old farts whose wives will shamelessly wear full-length chinchilla on any given day. And ohhhh heaven, the Chicago-cut done medium rare is about the best cow on a plate you'll get anywhere.  You absolutely have to make reservations (or else be a 20-year regular &/or a celebrity), otherwise, go kick rocks if you think you're going to get in. And then know that you'll be seated 60 mins later. This is the meatiest place on earth.

One sign that I've been living in the Valley for far too long: I forgot that in a city as vibrant as Chicago, people are still out and about even though it was already close to midnight on a Sunday.   We were on our way to our 9:30PM Sunday dinner reservation at Gibson's and I was fully expecting a restaurant that was either already empty or 'in the process' of emptying out.  To my surprise Gibsons was anything but - the bar area probably was twice as crowded as 99% of restaurants in the Valley at 7PM on a Friday (sad, but it won't be long before we bust out of here), the dining room was a cacophony of clinking glasses / silverwares and hubbub from diners happily tucking into their steaks, and as far as I could see, other places in the immediate locale that were just as crowded.   The downside: we had to wait about 15 minutes for our table to be ready, despite showing up on time for our reservation.  The upside: (1) I had some time to scout the surroundings: walls were covered with a bunch of black-and-white pictures of visiting celebrities (A-list and otherwise) and the restaurant felt like it was something out of the 1920s mob scene; (2) hostess was apologetic; and (3) our table was fantastic - it was on the side of the restaurant, in the covered patio area, perfect for peoplewatching.   Our server, one of the guys dressed in butcher-style shirts, was quick to attend to our table and to show the meat sample.  He pointed out the different cuts: London broil (12oz), small bone-in sirloin (14oz), small NY sirloin (12oz), filet mignon (8oz) and *gulp* W.R Chicago cut (22oz).   We skipped the appetizers and went straight to entree - W.R. Chicago for me and the hub, London Broil and sirloin for our friends.  We also had sides of fries, delicious creamed spinach and sauteed mushrooms, plus a bottle of Cab Sauv to wash it down.  The steak was tasty, it wasn't Alexander's Kobe but neither was the price (nor was I expecting it to be).  This awesome meal, that could have cost north of $80 in the Bay, ended up being $50 including tax and tip.

Quick Review!  Was on a work trip so a buddy and I stopped in for dinner on a Tuesday evening.  Loved the atmosphere. Completely packed, which was pretty shocking considering ive never seen a upscale this busy in Orange County...even on the weekend. Very nice people everywhere and overall great place to get drinks or dinner.  Food - 3/5  Honestly, the filet was no where near as good as Mastros. Dont get me wrong, it was good but wouldnt say it was top 5.  Service - 5/5 Awesome server. Very professional and friendly.  Atmosphere - 5/5  Place was really packed and fun.  Overall - 4/5 The atmosphere and service make up for the low steak score.

I've eaten a few times in Gibsons and think its the best steak house in Chicago. The service has always been great and the servers are very accommodating. While Chicago is packed full of steakhouses, few are in the same league as Gibsons. First off, the bread is better than any other steak house in Chicago. It might seem like a small thing but real quality restaurants look at the little details and bread is something that most places over look. Most people choose the Chicago Cut Rib Eye when they eat in Gibsons however they have a vast variety of steaks on the menu and I always try a different steak every time I go. The last time I went, I ordered the T-bone steak as I remembered it as something my mother would cook. The T-bone was so tasty and I enjoyed every bite. T-bone steak is an interesting cut of meat as it has meat from the Filet and the Sirloin so you have the best of both worlds. The salads that come with the steak look basic but are very fresh and taste better than they look. Much better than the Chop House' s salad. I've tried all the sides and they are all good, the Asparagus is my favourite. Overall a great steak restaurant however I still think Peter Lugers steak house in New York is better.

My husband wanted to eat here pretty bad, made reservations weeks in advance for 7:00 PM on a Friday- We get there 4 minutes after 7:00 and waited about 10 minutes before we were sat, the bar/waiting area was packed- Ladies, if the A/C is on when you go you will freeze-I was so happy to leave just to thaw out... So on to what's important, the food- FOOD: Ordered the Filet and with that comes a soup or salad, opted for the Lobster Bisque-It was good but actually a little too thick, usually I don't have that problem but it literally coated your teeth-Yet it had the taste that it should have, however I didn't see any lobster in mine- I asked for my filet to be cooked Rare, which it was, the waiter had given  my filet to my  husband but after he cut some pieces up he realized I had his Med. Rare and he had mine- Cooked perfect yet it had a little too much charring on it, so much that at the end it left a bad taste in my mouth-There were areas where it was solid black and crunchy- Environment was ok, I don't know why I care but the ceiling looked cheap, like a yellow brown spray painted on the ceiling-Tables are really close and I did notice something dumb, when trying to leave a table was being served food but that was the main exit out of the dining room to the waiting area, so it was just a big cluster of people wanting food, wanting to get by to leave and wanting to get by to be seated- Interesting mix of people in here, I can say that seeing ladies that were baked to a crisp with leathery skin made me glad I'm not obsessed with the sun-And glad my face has expression unlike many of the women that passed me-

So my roommate beat my in the Chicago Triathlon last year, so I owed him a dinner at Gibson's.  The food was so good I didn't even mind picking up the check at the end of our meal.  We both went into the meal expecting the best steaks of our lives, and that's exactly what we got.  We got the bone-in ribeye and the peppercorn crusted filet.  Both were perfectly cooked and delicious.  The peppercorn crust was a bit hot for my taste, but I would give the filet a slight edge over the ribeye.  We split the double-baked potato and creamed spinach--the sides are HUGE but perfect for splitting.  Last, but not least, order the blue cheese dressing on the starter salad.  I'm (obviously) a huge blue cheese fan, but this stuff is crazy good! One final note:  we had reservations for 8 PM on a Tuesday night.  The place was jammed and we weren't seated until 8:30 PM.  Go in expecting to wait....
There's no better place to stare at a 20-something lb porterhouse steak.  Too much for me, but very impressive.. Food is really rich - get ready to EAT. Great martinis and noisy good fun.

We heard so many great things about Gibson that we had to try it as part of our football weekend "to do" events. Here are my thoughts: 1.  Atmosphere and Location -- located in a pretty cute area of Chicago.  The night that we went in (Thursday in November), it was packed!  You could not walk through the bar at all.  Thank God, I booked reservations for dinner (highly recommended) 2.  Dining area -- well, to say that it is cramped is an understatement.  There is hardly any room to maneuver around.  I am pretty impressed that the waiter could navigate through the area.  As for the dining area itself, the tables were a bit too close.  If you are expecting a romantic dinner, please stay away from this place.  Literally, your ass is next to the next person in the next table.  You can hear every conversation that is going on... 3.  Entree -- well, before you order your meal, the waiter comes around with a tray of meat.  When I mean tray of meat.. it is raw bonafide meat.  He does a good job of going over what is what... honestly, just the sight of the meat causes you to lose your focus on what the waiter is telling you.  I had to ask him 2xs.... I chose the Porterhouse Steak cooked Med-rare (to this day, I can never understand why anyone orders a steak cooked WELL DONE -- yuck -- why don't they eat burnt wood).... Well, when the steak came out, let's say the steak was the size of my head.  It was that big.  No idea how I managed to finish it.  I should be on Man vs Food.  Anyways, honestly, despite the fact that I ate it all and the fries too, the steak was nothing special.  Like I said, because of the "massive" amount of steak, I found myself trying to focus on OINKING and gorging it down instead of appreciating the quality of the meat.  I was too full to consider whether it was a great meal or not.   My wife had some fish.  Apparently, she did not finish it ~ per her, it was a bit too dry and flaky.  Never order fish at a steakhouse... Overall, the atmosphere was a bit too crazy for me, the steaks were too massive, and the overall quality for the price does not see right. I give this a very average rating. Honestly, Outback Steakhouse would rank better...
Porterhouse was fantastic, maybe that best steak I've ever had,

When having people visiting, it's usually a toss up between Gibsons or Gene and Georgetti's.  Gibsons is usually very busy during the week with the business clientele but expect it to be packed on the weekend.  You get a good mix of crowd here with the young and hip State-Rush crowd mixing with the older professionals. The atmosphere is very good and the decor is typical steakhouse chic.  The bar is always a good place to get a drink and mingle before starting you Gibsons experience. Get a garbage salad to start your meal and you'll be pleasantly surprised.  The steaks are large and very good.  The porterhouse is very good but the double lamb chops are worth a try.  The prime rib is probably the best I've had in Chicago so far.  The creamed spinach and potatoes are always good sides. Gibsons is very good for steak and is near the very top on my list of Chicago steakhouses.  I can't give the place a 5-star rating because I judge steakhouses against Peter Luger's, and that'll never be trumped.  Expect to pay for what you get.  You can almost always find a Bull or Blackhawk at one of the tables after a home game, so it might be wise to pack a pen for an autograph.  Hasn't let me down yet.

I went to Gibson's for late night dining. Thumbs up for serving dinner at around midnight. I love the old school decor and ambiance of the place. The service was very good. If I remember it right, the server's name was Andrea and she was excellent! I had gin tonic and pear blossom martini; and I tried the rush st. Manhattan martini. All of them were very good. I ordered the planked whitefish with mashed potatoes and I was surprised how big the serving was. The fish tasted really good. The mashed potato presentation was very creative. My friend ordered the crab meat avocado and he said that it was very good too! The overall experience was great. It was expensive but I believe it was worth it!

Truthfully, what it comes down to for me when rating a steakhouse is the filet mignon. I wasn't as blown away with it as I thought I would be. It was a little tougher and fattier (hard to believe, I know) than what I would expect a rare-cooked filet to come out like.  Also, I dined with a group of 8, and I felt our waitress was very intimidated by our party and did not have control over the table. Sometimes you just want that, "Hey, we got it." feeling from your service team, and we didn't feel that whatsoever.  Sorry to say, but I vote Kinzie Chop House for the best filet, and to check out Morton's if you're looking for a similar traditional Chicago Steakhouse feel.

Sum up Gibson's in three words: Iconic Chicago Steakhouse.  Gibson's is keeping it old school (and delicious) with their white table linens, waiters in white jackets, piano bar, and celebrity photo lined hallways. My dad has visited me in Chicago four separate times and each time he insists on going to Gibson's. And you know what? It never disappoints.  The service is outstanding. Our waiter, Paco, was gracious enough to put up with my dad's questions: "Hey, how can I get my picture up on the wall?" and was super knowledgeable about the cuts of meat. In fact, one of my favorite parts is the presentation of the different cuts of beef (another dad question: "What do you guys do with this meat at the end of the night?").  The food is phenomenal. I went with the WR Chicago cut, which is a little fattier, but it just ups the flavor factor. The side dishes are huge and made for sharing. Whatever you do, please order the double-baked potato. It's as if angels come down from heaven and specially prepare these spudly nugget of creamy mashed deliciousness. They melt a thick layer of cheddar cheese on top to incubate the potato and make sure it stays nice and warm.  Wine list is expansive and while you think every bottle would be priced out of this world, you'd be wrong. They have bottles starting in the low 30s, which for a steakhouse, is a bargain.  Expect a heart attack at the end of the night from the bill (and quite potentially the food) but rest assured that it's well worth it for a meal & experience of this caliber.

This is the first review continued.   The other table we watched was the complete opposite.  She had a glass of champagne.  Who the hell orders champagne for dinner?  Sure, I do not enjoy champagne and think it is overrated.  Champagne is for the club and for hippity hop videos and songs.  Give me a cocktail or 4 any time over champagne.  Champagne is not for dinner.  But what the hell am I talk going on about?  We did not see them eating anything.  He had a glass of wine or a cocktail - I do not remember exactly - and they were talking and he did not seem overly interested in her.  This couple was entertaining and it was about to get more entertaining.   She was wearing a black dress with see-through panels throughout the body and legs of the dress.  She wanted to make sure that she was noticed by who was taking her out as well as everyone who she walked near.  We found her dress to be somewhat ridiculous and entertaining at the same time.  She was decent looking but by no means stunning which made her dress that much more entertaining.  It was simply a bit much considering where we were.  We then noticed that she got up from her side of the booth and sat on her knees on his side of the booth at which point they began to make out like junior high school.  It was thoroughly entertaining.  By this time there were fewer people in the place to observe such displays of affection.  Shortly after their make out session (or sessions) they left.  She ended up leaving at about the same time we did.  We did not notice the guy she was with though.   All in all it was the scene and the bar that made Gibson's a particularly fun evening.  Considering the quality of the steak I was served with I would recommend Ruth's Chris over Gibson's and that is all there is to it.  But for the bar scene, Gibson's was great and we will be back for that.   And why are people putting reviews for Hugo's here?

I like Hugo's for lunch on a summer day.  You may eat outside or near outside or feel like you're far from outside by eating in the dimly lit dining room.   I've been here twice this summer for lunch.  The crab cakes are excellent and so it the goat cheese appetizer.  The salad was average.   A long long time ago I had the best lobster ever for dinner here.  I still think about that lobster...mmmmm

3 1/2 yelp stars. decided to give it a shot based on all the great things you hear from all the chicago folks. it was okay... didn't blow me away or anything but typical steakhouse'esque.  Pros: -good service -good quality meat (USDA Prime) -good double stuff baked potato (potato + tons of cheese, how do u go wrong?) -fun ambiance -huge steakhouse servings (husband and i split the bone in rib eye) -perfectly cooked rare -steak comes with house salad or soup and salad was perfect size Cons: -steak was a bit plain tasting for my likings... i know there was salt, pepper, and seasoning on the table for me but i prefer my steaks to be somewhat seasoned by the chef -steak was cooked rare but too cold for my liking. i have this thing where i like my steaks rare but still warm.

The fillet was melting in my mouth.  One of the better steaks I have had in a long time. The dessert.  Let me state that I am not a fan of carrot cake.  Just never really liked any I have ever seen or tried.  This carrot cake was not like any previous encounters.  I really think highly of it.  And then there was this really good ice cream turtle dessert that was fabulous too. If someone else is buying a great place to drink.  Fortunately someone else was buying.

Went last night for anniversary.  Service was extremely hurried and not helpful.  Waiter did not have a good knowledge of the wines.  Food was good but not great.  Mrs. had the filet and I had the porterhouse.  Cooked correctly but steak not that flavorful.   If you are going to spend the $, go elsewhere.  I recommend Joe's.

I took my bf there for his birthday last Oct. because he said Gibson's is his boss's favorite steakhouse in Chicago. It has been awhile but there are still several things that are memorable:  Atomsphere--the interior is very classy and old school. It felt more like a family-style dinning restaurant than a romantic restaurant. Even though it says here the attire is dressy, there were enough people in jeans and t-shirts. Also it could be quite loud so if you are looking for a quiet and romantic dinner, this is not the place for you.  Food--we ordered some appetizer, BUT I don't remember what exactly we had. All I could remember is how BIG my bf's steak was. I think he ordered the smaller of the two porterhouse cuts, yet it's still probably the largest cut I've seen. And my bf said it was very tender and yummy. I had the fillet, medium well (I don't like seeing pink in my food unless it's waygu), it was pretty yummy but I'm not the steak expert to say whether it's the best. We also had asparagus as side, very fresh and enough to share for two.  Dessert--Okay here's the key, their dessert is HUGE! I mean HUGE! I am a dessert person so we've never taken home any dessert, except here. We had the chocolate mousse cake, both of us together probably only finished 1/3. We boxed the remaining and I had it for breakfast and lunch the next day... Anyways, just because the quantity was big doesn't mean they lack the quality. I think their dessert was very very yummy. So if you want go somewhere to satisfy your dessert craving, Gibson's is the place for you.  P.s. we didn't order this, but a table next to us ordered the bigger or larger than life cake--it was even bigger than my chocolate mousse cake, and it looked delicious! I will definitely try that next time.

Hello Gibsons--it's been a long time. Nearly 10 years since we've seen each other. I just couldn't bring myself to see you again, we had such a bad break up. But now I remember all the things I loved about you. The exceptional service, the people watching, the delicious (delicious) filet mignon, the extensive wine selection, the lemon drop martinis, and a pretty nice side of spinach with button mushrooms. And you let me sit outside on a beautiful night. I love you again Gibsons. I love you, I do!

We were there as part of our convention. Shoppertrak if you must know...  Pretty typical steak house. The volume of people speaking was very, very loud.  Anyways, Here is the menu:  House salad - AWESOME. Awesome dressing, perfect size, great salad.  Fillet - I had ordered Med Rare, but it was closer to Med. Not juicy, I have had better at my house, but I love grilling, so seeing no grill marks, seeing no charred parts or pieces, made me suspicious when I saw the steak...Iffy at best.  Sides - Green beans - Good. Baked/double baked potato. I like eating the skins with my potato, and this one sucked mega time. Not only was the skins SUPER DUPER cooked and crunchy, they were borderline uneatable.  Red Wine was served - I have no idea of brand or blend, but...ok house red. If you like it dry or full bodied, it was not for you.  Coffee and desert were fine. Key Lime was AWESOME. The crust was phenomenal. The tart and sweet were Perfectly balanced....AWESOME AWESOME desert! Beyond A+ there.  Rooms and setup were ok. I found it very odd that they did not offer a pepper mill and maybe a salt mill. The salt and pepper shakers were ones I'd expect at a McDonald's and definitely not on par for a top end steak house. Plus, their house seasoning was loaded with salt...and it wasn't even that good.  I'd take the wife, but I'd expect to pay a minimal amount.  Last time I was in Chicago, we ate at The Grill Room and it was great, this was not up to their par, but good none the less.

What's not to love about big ass steaks and lobster tails so succulent you swear you can't eat the whole thing...and yet you do! Been to Gibsons a few times over the years and it still delivers. Located in the hub of the Chicago dining scene, the streets are always alive with smiling and happy restaurant-goers.  Place was packed, but we had an 8 pm reservation and yet barely had time to take a sip of our drinks in the bar before our table was ready. Thank you prompt hostess! For a variety of reasons, I seem to be always wearing black when we dine out and am impressed when a restaurant provides black linen napkins to replace the standard white lint-filled ones. This keeps white lint from sticking all over the front of my outfit and keeps me crisp and lint free. Thank you kind server! Server was informed and educated on the menu. They do a dinner display similar to Morton's where they bring examples of the steak and lobsters to your table to chat with you about the specials and such. It gives you an idea of what's to come. Big. Ass. Steaks. Hubby and I started with the seafood gumbo (spectacular), followed by the wedge salad (pretty damn good as far as wedge salads go) with our entrees as the encore. I of course had the lobster and Hubby had the bone-in rib eye. Lobster was perfect but Hubby's steak was overcooked. Not enough to pitch a fit about, but enough that it was worth mentioning since it was ordered medium which means slightly pink in the center and there was no pink to be seen. Server had Hubby cut through the whole thing to confirm it was overdone and then whisked it away. After that, it seemed like every person working that night came over to apologize. Seriously? It wasn't that big of a deal. It's just that Gibsons is committed to quality food and service and want to get it right 100% of the time. I think the janitor even apologized. Kidding, but you get what I'm saying. But once that perfectly-cooked steak arrived at the table....OMG. Melt-in-you-mouth-tender. Thank you experienced Chef! Mashed potatoes were ok. I prefer mine a little creamier but that might be a California thing. No room for dessert of course, but just seeing the ginormous portions of cake they call a slice....there was no way I was going there. I know my limits. What more is there to say? Good drinks. Great food. Fun ambiance. Gibsons delivers the goods!

Gibson's is certainly a top-tier steakhouse with giant sized portions.  Their desserts were massive and could probably serve 4-5 people!  If the steak itself was more memorable, I might have given it 5 stars.

We had a great lunch.  Lobster salad and Planked Whitefish.  With a bottle of wine.  Delicious! Upper end for us.  Special occasion. Enjoyable experience. Great waitress.  Enjoyed eating indoors streetside, the best of both worlds. Would go again.  Fresh greens, great presentation and good eating with great service.

We had some issues with the service when we went to Gibsons. We made a reservation but still had to wait over 20 minutes. Fine, it's Gibsons. Then, my Brother-In-Law and I both ordered the Chicago Cut as Medium and Medium Rare respectively. Our steaks came well done. That's a big difference, and the single thing you should get right as a famous steakhouse. Even my Wife's Filet Mignon which she ordered Medium was severely overcooked. Our waitress rudely suggested we had ordered them well done. I've never ordered one well done in my entire life. The managers were kind enough to see the waitresses mistake and have the steaks taken back. The steaks that were cooked correctly were absolutely phenomenal (though we thought my bro-in-law's was still overcooked a little). The sides were average, but, that's not the draw at a steakhouse. The managers were kind enough to give us free desert and were continually apologetic, so I respect that quite a bit, hence the four stars. Additionally, if the steaks wouldn't have been so incredible, I would have gone with two or three stars. I recommend Gibsons despite the poor service experience as it was the best steak I've ever had, getting the nod over Ruth Chris' as well as the many other exceptional steaks in and out of this town.

With over 300 reviews, what more can be said? The steaks are phenomenal, services is outstanding and people watching is priceless.  Hubby had the porterhouse and double baked potato and the steak was like buttah!  He is a true carnivore and manly man-meaning he loves to eat meat.  He was in Heaven with his meal.  It should be noted that there are two sizes and he had the smaller portion.  I truly don't see how anyone could eat the larger size alone.  I had the lamb chops with asparagus and Hollandaise sauce.  I love lamb chops and thought no one could beat Wildfire but a coworker told me to try Gibson's.  I was a bit skeptical at first bc after all, this is a steakhouse.  I'm a firm believer in getting the dish that the restaurant is best known for but I am a convert.  Being in the upper class establishment that is Gibson's I tried to be all prim and proper with my lamb chops but I gotta tell you, when I couldn't get my knife and fork to get all of the meat off the bone, I picked it up with my fingers and finished it that way.  Yes I did!  Yeah, yeah, I know where I was and I realized that at any moment some big muckety muck could have walked in and seen me-imagine the horror!  But I did not care.  Those chops were ridiculous and I was determined to enjoy every last morsel.   Desert was a slice of pecan pie that was as big as my head-well maybe not my head because it's pretty big-but as big as a normal sized head.  The crust was nice and buttery and the pecans were carmelized just right.  Drinks were some martinis that I can't recall because they were good in flavor and with the alcohol.  Can be a bit pricey with drinks and desert but worth every penny.

Doesn't get better than Gibsons when it comes to a steakhouse. The food and service were phenomenal as well as the company. The only minor complaint was that my ribeye was more towards the medium side than medium rare but it was still delicious. First off, we had the pleasure of sitting next to Torii Hunter since we were in town for the Angels/Cubbies series and he was the nicest guy. We bumped into him in the lobby and said hello and he started talking to us again while we were at dinner. Very personable and thankful which is uncommon for pro athletes. He even autographed the menu and addressed it to my dad for a cool fathers day gift. Anyways, our server looked like a mini version of Kobe Bryant and he was amazing. Provided us with great service and he was super friendly.  I had the bone in ribeye, my girlfriend had a NY strip and we got some asparagus and mushrooms and spinach for sides. Everything was cooked to perfection minus my steak being more on the medium side than medium rare.  Since we just celebrated my B-day Kobe Jr. brought us out a giant slice of pecan pie that was literally 5 inches thick and the size of a third of a pie. It was phenomenal.  Lastly, my girlfriend was excited because Julianna and Bill were sitting next to us (E News and Apprentice winner who now have a reality show) for dessert at the end of the night. Gibsons is a must for any steak lover!

You'd better be hungry if you go here!  On the menu: Steak the size of your face A cheese-stuffed baked potato An entire head of broccoli -No exaggeration! The veggie option was a half pound of pasta with veggies. Literally. Maybe even more. PS, try a dirty gin marini, it's gooood. America, f*ck yeah!

We love a good steak, so on our trip out to Chicago for the Angel/Cubbies series from Orange County we had to check it out. First, the service was excellent - I dont know our servers name but he looks-no kidding- exactly like Kobe Bryant. Only about 5 feet shorter.  He was a good sport when we downed our wine and I nicknamed him "Kobe Slider". The setting is dark and constantly packed. We sat next to Tori Hunter (from the Angels) and Chicago residents Giuliana and Bill Rancic. Funny that we are from LA and saw more celebrities in Gibsons than anywhere we eat in Southern Cal.  The bread basket has several types of bread- white, french, wheat, olive, etc. They were good and fresh- and like most break baskets, not even necessary (not that it stopped me from eating it). We had a starter salad which comes with each entree. Nothing fancy- iceburg, tomatoes, bleu cheese dressing. I would have expected a fancier salad but the dressing was actually really delicious.  I had the petit New York strip and my boyfriend had the Chicago Style bone in ribeye. For sides we had asparagus (Kobe Slider suggested we get it grilled with lemon and olive oil- amazing), sauteed mushrooms, and spinache sauteed in garlic and olive oil. The sides were perfect. They reccomended the split potato, but we decided since we were already eating our weight to go with the veggies. The mushrooms were sauteed in a wine sauce and had great flavor. They also put in chunks of roasted garlic which made the spinach and mushrooms even more awesome.  The steaks were both HUGE. I had the petit so I cant imagine the size of the regular. I had it medium rare and it was perfectly cooked with a nice seared char- crust on the outside. It was perfect- easily one of the best I have ever had. His ribeye was also perfect, although he did say it was cooked slightly more toward the medium side.  Of course we had dessert. They have cakes and pies that are literally about 7 inches high (thats what she said) and about 1/4 of a huge pie per slice. We were going to get lemon  meringue, but Kobe slider told us he was bringing us something better. Uh, ok. He was right- and brought us a giant slice of pecan pie. It was amazing, and was topped with ice cream. All in all it was an awesome meal, great service, fun people watching, and a cool atmosphere.

I've had better.... To start, let's give it up for the shrimp cocktail!  So fresh and with amazing cocktail sauce, you can't go wrong!  I came here with my boyfriend's family and we all enjoyed a juicy piece of steak.  The steak was cooked to all of our likings, but it wasn't anything special.  We ordered the asparagus, mushrooms, and the mashed potatoes side dishes.  The asparagus had no flavoring to it and the mashed potatoes were a basic side of mashed potatoes.  I guess I was expecting a little more pizazz for the price. If you're looking to go out for a nice steak dinner downtown I would probably point you in a different direction...

My first dinner here and 2nd for my wife.  We came here to celebrate a friends 40th birthday, so the drinking started a bit early in the limo, a few martinis in the bar and then finally dinner.  The Philly Flyers were in town for the Stanley Cup match and were coming down the stairs from their private dining room on the 2nd floor as I was exiting the washroom upstairs.  Had the urge to topple the whole group over and give our Hawks an edge for game 5 (Hawks won anyway without my help).  My point here is that this place PULLS in a lot high profile visitors to the city. Food: Three of us ordered the bone-in fillet ($50) and the forth ordered fish off the Hugo's menu (they are owned by the same group and our waiter suggested a look at the menu when my friend's wife asked about fish specials).  The bone in came highly recommended as only a few restaurants in the country have access to the cut.  The steaks were very good, but not the best fillet I ever had; especially given the price.  We also split a lobster tail and it was very good.  They pre-cut it into six sections for easier sharing. Dessert: Key Lime pie was enough for 4. Service: Carl and assisted by Paco.  Both were top notch! Overall:  Chances are you will run into some celebrity if dining here for dinner.  If you can live without that, I prefer Smith and Wollensky on the Chicago River for steaks.

************* REVIEW 150 **************** Our regular spot for steak, 1 block from my old place, can't beat that convenient. This is probably 1 of the most famous steakhouse in the country & I can tell you by they are the top 20 grossing in 2009 of all restos in the country.  I'm not surprised by this. The steak is consistent here, top notch cuts that there is out there, especially the the bone-in rib eye, a classic all around American steakhouse. Their burger is really good here too. Great wines list, efficient service, & I love the outdoor patio for people watching! What i'm not too crazy about this place is the service, hit & miss. They are always too packed, so the servers always seem to rush us out.  Even we had RSVP, still waited for 25 minutes!  Overall: 4 stars For value 4 stars For Food: 4 stars For Service: 3 stars  For ambiance: Classic American Steakhouse. For location: 1 of the happening spots of the Gold Coast & 1 of the more popular with politicians.

I was told that Donald Trump is a regular patron at Gibson's Steakhouse, and thus began my mission to eat there.  The wife and I trekked nearly 2 miles in 88 degree heat and humidity to have lunch on a Sunday afternoon.  We were seated immediately, and ordered the W.R. Chicago Cut ribeye and Marinated Skirt Steak.  I was actually really impressed with the skirt steak which was juicy, tender, flavorful, and cooked medium.  I have never had skirt steak cooked this perfectly before.  The medium-rare W.R. Chicago Cut ribeye was an excellent piece of meat that was crusty outside and savory juices were flowing out after the first cut.  I recommend trying the steak without steak sauce first since you will find that it's already seasoned perfectly. My only regret is that I did not save room for dessert.  Apparently, Gibson's desserts are renowned. To sum-up my experience, I have this message for Gibsons: Damn you!  You have bastardized every piece of meat I eat in the future. I'm back in California, 1700 miles away.  I miss you already. :'o(

This is the place to be, came in here on a Thursday nite, place what packed had to wait by the bar with my friends for our reservation. Steaks all around. Our server was very attentive yet laid back..if that makes sense. Drinks were drinks. but overall a good time!

The star is for the service that is always good at Gibsons. We dined here on Friday night and many times before and we can only say that the food quality is going down,while prices are going up. If you pay $50,- for a steak, it has to be perfect.I had the bone in filet mignon. The meet was burned from the outside and raw and cold inside. We sent it back and ordered they're signature steak instead. This one was like dog food and more broiled than grilled. The starter sides were discusting. The lobster bisque more like eating a stick of butter. Don't come here, it's a total rip off. You can get a better meal for half the price at weber grill or just throw one on at home.

Ehhhh, its ok.  I went here for a dinner.  I got the salmon....literally that is all it was...absolutely no flavor.  I know its a steak house, but still.  I almost doused it with A1 to give it a little something. Another really weird thing, the waiter poured a full bottle of wine like an empty one...literally tipping it almost all the way upside down so wine was splashing all over.... For an upscale place, I wasnt impressed....

Glad that we made a reservation for this place...because they didn't seat us until 30 minutes after our reservation! :P They definitely made up for it in ambiance, service and their food. The Bar: There are a lot of older men here on the prowl. yikes!  Definitely much more men than women here. No thank you, but if you are looking for that sort of thing, I guess this is the place to be! The Service: Our server was Elvis, yes Elvis I am giving you a shot out. He kept pointing out the window and swears that he was pointing out Oprah, mentioned that Julia Roberts was in the place last week, and thought that I looked like Ann Curry. He was entertaining. The food: They bring out the raw meat selections before you actually order. I was eyeing the Chicago cut, but our server kept suggesting that I would probably go for the filet. I don't think he has seen a little asian chick finish a big steak like that before. I got the Chicago cut medium rare. It has got to be one of the best steaks I've ever had. It was HUGE, but I finished it. Our server also gave us an extra potato...like we needed it with all that meat. He also brought a complimentary dessert (chocolate mousse cake). But I think that if you are visiting Chicago, this place is a must. I had enough meat for about a month...and honestly went on a vegetarian diet for the next few days.

So I have this friend from NYC who doesn't eat dairy of any kind and basically lives on steaks and potatos, mostly from very high end NYC establishments that charge $50+ for an 8 oz filet (it's highway robbery, I don't want to talk about it). I've tried warning him about his arteries (and his bank account)... but a man's gotta eat, right?   Anyways, we were in town for a friend's wedding and despite his hemming and hawing about nothing can beat Peter Luger's, he agreed to try Gibson's. He looked at me in total disbelief when the waiter explained 1. that the small filet mignon was 32$ and 2. that it was 10 oz.  It was the best piece of steak he has ever eaten and as twisted as this will sound to anybody outside of NYC, the cheapest. Meanwhile, I feel vindicated and proud of my hometown for out-steaking Lugers.

I have had many a meal and many a cocktail here back in my "important downtown businessman" days. It's a great spot for a decent filet or sirloin steak.  But now I like to belly up to the bar every once in awhile, as I did on Mother's Day, and have a martini, and perhaps a lite bite. Where the heck else can you end up sitting next to a some steel magnate, who has two Rolls-Royce vehicles and a Bentley (the latter which he has shipped out by train when he is on the west coast,) a bartender who tells you this stuff, and who  can regale you with those long and politically incorrect jokes which go on for days before the punch line? In such a milieu, and where I know that no-one will remember me from one visit to the next, I like to pretend to talk sports-something I am totally ignorant about, but I just repeat what I hear other guys say. Such as, "boy, there were some really bad calls last night!" And the other guys just take that and run with it,. I find that most of them don't really listen anyway, so it doesn't matter too much WHAT you say. Fake sports talk-probably more prevalent than you thought. I know this has nothing to do with Gibson's service or food, but I think we a "Field Guide to Chicago Neighborhoods," like they do with wildlife or birds. A couple of entries: First, the Small-Breasted Golden Cougar. She has the year-round tan, the German Skeleton face (think Joan Rivers in the 80's), the blond rich lady hair, tight, tight jeans, even if she's 70-something, the heels and a smart little bag. Then there's the bland-looking 20-something guy in blue and white seersucker shorts, dock-siders, the Ralph Lauren navy windbreaker, and a pink polo shirt underneath. He is perhaps The white-throated, Yale trained money-grabber. Come on, you just wouldn't find these birds in Albany Park. Gibson's is fun for martinis or bird-watching or pretending to be something you're not. And Amen to that.

Geez, I really hate to wait especially when I've got a reservation. Its just no fun being crammed into a small bar space with a host of international conventioneers, but I guess that's what I get for making a dinner reservation at this Chicago steak institution during a major city convention. 20 minutes after our reservation time luckily my party was seated. Just walking into the dining room here is a scene and some of the best people watching around. The food is always good at Gibsons. Have I ever had a bad meal here? Surely not that I can remember but with huge portions all around who can even remember when you're leaving here in a food-coma? You see the cut of meats you know what you're ordering. Let me recommend though the strip steak with the fried onions. Meat heaven. I love it so much and luckily it's a huge portion so that means I can have dinner the next night too. Baked potatoes are on steroids so plan to split accordingly. Desserts are fun to order just for the sheer shock value but the turtle pie with hazelnuts and ice cream galore is too sweet to miss.
Stumbled on this place as a tourist for a late dinner. Great service, big servings of good food and a friendly waiter. Even the restroom was top notch. You won't go wrong here.

I went here to try the Burger, to see if it was list-worthy.  (it is).  I have been here a couple other times as well, on someone else's dime, and would highly recommend the steaks and desserts.  Here's a review of a recent visit: We set a reservation on Open Table, which was acknowledged by the maitre'd, Raul.  He gave us the option, so we chose the bar for the excellent Viagara Triangle people watching. The burger wasBri very good  We got the burgers medium rare with cheddar cheese.  The cheese appeared to have been placed on the bun prior to the brioche bun being toasted. It was think and very melty.  The burger was super-juicy, and the meat was of eviednt high quality.  It was large, but not too big.  The fries were great as well.  Overall, this SHOULD be the Gibson's burger.  Traditional and high-quality.  Not Innovative in the least, but impeccably executed. The service was wonderful.  Our server (Ann, I think) treated us the same as the customers who were ordering $50 steaks, even though our total bill was $32.  She was also not hard on the eyes.  As mentioned, we booked our reservation through Open Table, and I had marked that it was our first visit (well, the first time paying).  I think for that reason, we got a fantastic Hot Fudge sundae to split.  Free.  Definitely worth the white lie.   Sodas were $2.75 each, which is less than most of the other big steakhouses.  Strangely, everyone around us got mini-bottles and glasses with ice. Mine came pre-poured and was extremely watery... They also have a large bread basket.  The bread today was raisin, multigrain, and a crusty French bread.  I tried all of them, and they were very good.

Gibson's is as good as it gets. If you want to experience a Chicago steakhouse, Gibson's is the place to go. The portions are huge (especially the desserts that feed 10) and every cut is juicy, flavorful, and melts in your mouth. Seafood is delicious as well and flown in fresh daily (from Alaska mostly). It is always crowded so dinner is not quiet, but the atmosphere is fun. Absolutely worth every penny!

Off the hook restaurant. Old school steak house that was crazy busy. The steaks are excellent cooked to perfection. The pork chop was one of the best I have ever had. The side of fries was huge and some of the best fries.   Your meal comes with either soup or salad....I loved the salad with their famous bleu cheese dressing. The deserts are ridiculous...the turtle pecan pie was enough for 5-6 people...it was friggin large. I love chicago for restaurants like this.

A buddy of mine suggested lunch here today.  Nothing too special about the decor. The waitress was very attentive and checked on us a few times and asked if we needed more drinks. We both had the 14 oz filet mignon. We ordered it medium rare. It was a bit undercooked, the meat was cold when we first bit into it. We asked our waitress if we could have it cooked for just a bit longer and she brought it back in. When she brought it back out it was cooked perfectly just right.  The filet was huge, very thick, came with a dipping sauce that paired well with it. We also had a seafood soup, which was very good. All in all the filet was delicious, I wouldn't say its the best I've ever had, but I would definitely come here again.

Now, I love my Yelp app on  my iPhone. My boyfriend and I were walking on Michigan Ave on our vacation, wanting a good steak. After search on Yelp, we  decided on Gibson's.  Please keep in mind that it was a Tuesday afternoon, so there was NO crowd at all!  We were seated right and way. The waitress (Erin) was the best! She was attentive and able to answer any questions I had. My pear blossom martini was to die for! Light and crisp, not sugary at all. I inquired about the WR Chicago cut steak (a 21 oz rib-eye with the bone in). I asked for medium and I got medium. So freakin tender with a nice outside. Yum! I was so impressed. And so happy with the service and my meal!

You can't call yourself a Chicagoan and skip Gibson's. This is a review for the bar area only, as I haven't dined here in probably 20 years. My SevenStar companion and I wandered in here for a cocktail the other day, which was fun 'cos I get regaled with tales of his bad behavior . . . in the past. ;-) Yeah, it's the Viagra Triangle. But . . . that crowd does know quality, and good bartenders. The bartenders here are the real deal, very friendly and great at their job. Martinis are icy and beautifully crafted. Mmm! This is a REAL oldskool bar for oldskool people . . . and the place has always been great for people watching. The lobster and artichoke appetizer was tasty. I don't know why, but I would have preferred that it be a hot appetizer. At any rate, I happily noshed on it, 'cos hello . . . lobster? Are you going to turn that down? I'm not that kind of girl, I'll always enjoy me some lobster!

I have a hard time even giving Gibson's Two Stars after our last visit there on Saturday night.  Now, granted it was a Saturday night, and we didn't have reservations.....but if the wait was going to be over 2 hours, tell us that up front. We got there at 7pm, and were told by the Hostess that the wait for a table for two was "20 minutes, 30 minutes at the most".  After waiting 45 minutes and spending over $50 bucks at the bar on two rounds of drinks (rocks glass is SMALL by the way), we checked with the hostess and she said "we're very busy, it will be another 15-20 minutes".  Another $27 dollar round of drinks and 30 minutes later, she again says "15 minutes".  So, we wait the 15 minutes and check again...."the tables are paid, we're just waiting for them to get up".  We wait another 20 minutes and finally she calls our name.  The hostess walks us through the dining room and back into the back of the bar, to a table in the bar.  "no, we've waited over 2 hours for a table in the bar? We could have had a table in the bar a long time ago"   At this point, we're ready to leave and never come back.  We've spend over $120 at the bar and stood 140 minutes getting bumped around.  The host gets the manager, who does offer to get us a free drink as they get us another table.  Finally, after 2 1/2 hours we get seated.   We both ordered the "Small Fillet" which isn't that small....10 ounces.  (This is where they get two stars rather than only one)  The steak was very good.....good enough for a 2 1/2 hour wait.....well NO.  It was good, not great.  Mashed potatoes were AVERAGE, gravy was AVERAGE.  Mushrooms were GOOD.  Calimari was VERY GOOD, better than most places.   Will we go back even with a reservation?  Nope....there are just too many good places to pick from, and when I can get just as good a steak or better at many of them, why bother?   Our bill with all the drinks was almost $300 with tip.  Not worth it if you ask me.  The hostess staff is rude, the bar is crowded and the room to stand waiting for a table is crowded.....so, waiting is not a good option.  If it's going to take 2+ hours for a small table, tell me that, don't tell me "20 to 30 minutes".
We love this place, steaks were great! sides were good, but the ranch they brag about doesn't own up... on the ranch rating 2 out of 10.  Can't wait to go back for the Lobster!

Mmmmmm go here once a month. Bone in rib eye is my fave but so is the bone in filet. Depends on how hungry but it' hard to finish either one. Had the strip and was not a fan. Chowder is amazing, asparagus, spinach all good but ask for no butter or sauce on side. Mushrooms - great addition with the steak. And drum roll please........turtle pie for dessert with a side of the chocolate and caramel sauce. Talk about heaven - actually my favorite dessert in the world. Need about 8 people to finish but who cares, get it take some bites and be satisfied.  Love Gibsons. I don't care that its in the viagra triangle or that theres a lot of tourists. If you want go steak cooked right this is the spot.

Probably the most average steak house in the city.  Service was average, Drink prices were high.  Expected steak to be perfect, but I was wrong.  Not sure why quality differs from location to location.  Agree with other reviews, the clientele is old.

My husband and I were in Chicago for the weekend and were starving when we went looking for a place to catch lunch.  While this is not the first place that you would think of for a late lunch on the weekend, it was just what we were looking for.  Locals at the table next to us tried to warn us about the portion sizes.  In the back of my mind, I thought, "They have not seen us eat!".  They told us to split a sandwhich, but we had been up since the crack of dawn, flown into town, checked into the hotel and tried to catch lunch at three other restaurants that has too long of a wait.   We were hungry!  We ordered our own sandwiches and when they came out, I could not believe my eyes.  The thing was HUGE.  I am from Texas and I am telling you, this thing was large.  But even better, it was not all about quantity, the food was really well prepared.  My husband had the steak sandwich, I had the blackened salmon sandwich.  Sooo good.  The locals were not kidding about the dessert.  We spotted a table that had ordered a "piece" of pie.  I think it could have served ten.  Even better, the service was great and I think out bill may have been $20.  What a steal!

I've been coming here since I was a kid and this place is Hands Down my favorite restaurant in Chicago. Actually besides Wrigley it might be my favorite place in Chicago.  Service: calling it excellent would be unfair to this place. The servers are better than fantastic. Very attentive but not intrusive and overbearing. Mo is our regular server and he is not only hilarious but extremely educated on all the wines,meats, sides, seafood, and appetizers. Mo always buys dessert(which I'll get to later)and an after dinner drink for my table. The bartenders are always real gentlemen that will buy rounds of drinks for everyone.They are as polite as can be and can offer an opinion on pretty much any topic if asked.  Atmosphere and Decor: This place is a landmark with pictures of every celebrity you could imagine hanging on the walls. You never feel rushed.In face one time we sat for dinner at 9 and we didn't leave until 1AM. Of course the place was packed the whole time and still had a ton of people at the bar when we were leaving. The place is extremely classy without being the least bit pretentious.  Food:The food is expensive but if your going out for a great steak at one of the best steak houses in the world expect to spend $40-60 on steak. And did I mention the steaks are enormous. They can feed you for the next few days.The best part is even though the steak is huge the product is never compromised. They are always cooked perfect to order and are so juicy. I also like how they tell you that you shouldn't eat anything past medium and they won't cook well done because it cheapens the meat.Any steak lover knows the rarer the steak the better the flavor.The sides are enormous and delicious.I've been to many steak houses where the sides are $15 and you get a baseball size baked potato. Not here. The Creamed spinach is my favorite but I've tried all and they are all fantastic.I have had better steaks at other steak houses but the fact that you get a monster steak for a reasonable price,cooked perfect there is no steak house better.The dessert is usually complimentary and 1 piece of cake is the size of human head. It is so big they actually serve it with a steak knife so you can cut through it. I've had roughly 5 different desserts and Even though there is never room in my stomach I always manage to have a piece and they have all been fantastic.  Wine: The wine list is enormous and unlike most other 5 star restaurants all the wines are so fairly priced. They don't attempt to get $100 for a $10 bottle of wine like other places. They offer $40 wines for $75 which is unheard of for most great restaurants.  That being said this is top 3 of my all time favorite restaurants and def #1 in terms if steak houses. Chicago has many great steak joints in this city but nothing competes with the overall experience of Gibsons

Come in. Put in your name to reserve a table knowing the wait may take longer than an hour. No big deal. Go to the bar. Order a tiny-triple  Martini.  Drink it. Order a second one, but this time ask the bartender to put it in a rocks glass so you won't  spill it again. Hang out and enjoy the crowd. Tables ready. Follow the hostess over to the table by the window. Awesome spot. Listen to your waiters presentation. Choose the filet.  Mashed taters. Order a glass of Cab.  Go to the bathroom. Pee. Wash your hands. Go back to your table. Waiter delivered the food. (Pulp Fiction technique). Food looks great. Your filet is aweome but try not to eat like a caveman. Notice the tiny young lady sitting at the next table with the incredibly gigantic steak on her plate that looks like it weighs about 7 pounds, no kidding. Must be the Porterhouse. Her "grandfather" is paying the check so  it's her duty to order the most expensive thing on the menu. Laugh and have fun. Finish dinner.  Pay the check. Great service, tip accordingly.

THE place to go for a special occasion (or when you're not paying!).  Whenever I'm in town for work I make sure to make a reservation for my colleagues on our last night.  You can't go wrong with any of the steaks.  Be prepared to eat a LOT, and don't be afraid to share.  The side dishes alone are enough to feed a small village.  Make sure to save room for dessert (good luck with that).  The Macadamia Nut pie will blow. your. mind.  You'll just have to find room.

The first time I went here after moving to Chicago, I was unimpressed. Maybe it was b/c it Friday night before a Bears home game.  Everyone from Philly was there eating and the service kinda sucked.  One memorable moment from that night included this back and forth with my wife- Me:  It looks like that girls is having dinner with her grandfather - Liz: Grandfather's don't touch their granddaughter's like that.  Welcome to the Viagra Triangle!! Second time we went was with a friend in town from SF.  This time was on a weekday and was impressed.  The food, drinks, and service all were excellent.

It's Valentine's Day.  Yes, we celebrate.  Any excuse to get into the city & get steak in our bellies.   Traffic to the city for this suburban couple was almost enough to have us turn back (almost double the usual hour!)  I was almost certain that our table would be long gone when we pulled up to this Gold Coast landmark an hour and a half late.  We were seated within 5 minutes, no questions asked!  Talk about accommodating!  They also offer complimentary coat check. In true Valentine's Day fashion, we were literally elbow to elbow the next table over.  Boo!  But all was forgiven when our steaks arrived.  Went with my usual filet mignon medium.  It was absolutely melt in your mouth tender with a slight charred bite.  Sides here are slightly larger than at Ruth's Chris & Morton's so don't go overboard when ordering!

One of the best restaurants in America.   The seafood and steaks and creamed spinach are tops.   Their wine list is incredible.   Most of all, their staff are so helpful and smart.   Once I came here with a friend for dessert.   It was late, the kitchen had just closed.   I told the waiter that my friend was visiting from St. Louis and she had a brain tumor.   The waiter reopened the kitchen for us, brought us two giant desserts and then three waiters sat with us and told us stories about the restaurant.   My friend is gone now, but the memories of that night live on.   Thank you.

We had visited Chicago for the weekend as a celebration of two birthdays.  My boyfriend (it was his birthday that we were celebrating) loves Gibson's and makes it a point to visit every time he goes to Chicago.  The other couple that we were traveling with had not been there so there was a lot of anticipation.  From the food to the outstanding service, Gibson's did not disappoint.  I had booked reservations on  opentable.com  a month beforehand knowing that a reservation is a MUST especially on a weekend night during primetime.  I expected to wait a bit in the bar even though we had made the reservations and so a twenty minute wait was expected.  The hostess apologized and in turn gave us a terrific table along the windows.  The waiter Carl was outstanding and entertaining as well.  We ordered steaks of course and shared a salmon plate as well.  After stuffing our selves in traditional Gibson's fashion, of course we wanted the macadamia nut pie.  Carl informed us that the monstterous pie would be complimentary because of the wait for our table.
