The food, service and ambiance was everything that we promised the couple that was with us and I'm sure Gibson's will become a tradition for them as well.

Me:  Hi Mr. Filet Mignon how do you do today?  Filet:  I'm doing great man, any questions before we get started? Me:  Well why don't you just tell me about yourself.   Filet:  Well I'm 14 ozs of melt in your mouth prime cut steak.  I'm cooked to perfection and slightly charred so you know I'm good.  I would suggest you pair me with a double baked potato, to double your pleasure.  Actually here he is now. Me:  Yo Potato how you doing? Potato:  I'm doing good.  Just to let you know I'm about the size of your fist and loaded with melted cheese, so I hope you brought your appetite. Me:  Well, I'm kind of intimidated by the size of you two, are you sure I'll be ok?  I mean I was hardly able to take down those arm sized shrimp that you serve here, don't know if I can take down you two. Filet:  Don't be such a wuss.  You'll be fine.  I would never lie. Me:  Ok I guess it's time to chow down. Filet:  Enjoy! Me: nom nom nom (two hours later after waking from a food induced coma) Me: Wow that was good. The End.

I have been coming to Gibsons for years now, at least once a year with the boys. Always a warm welcome and great service.  It starts with a drink at the bar waiting for the group to gather and enjoying the scenery... I don't go to pick up but the possibilities are there, some even aged like the steaks.  Off to the table where the service is prompt, we usually have the same server and despite the time away he seems to have an amazing recollection of who we are. I usually have the Chicago Cut and we all share some potatoes, asparagus and other delicious sides to complement the meat with a good bottle of Red. Dessert is an occasional addition to the meal, that is if there is room. Desserts are as big as the Steaks so you should consider sharing.  After Dinner back to the bar for a drink and the occasional chit chat with the other patrons.  Always a great time.

On my first visit to the downtown location of Gibsons, probably Chicago's best-known steakhouse for the past 20 years, I can't help but give it 5 stars as it was certainly superlative. But if I could award 1/2 star increments, I think 4-1/2 would be more apt as it was not quite perfect.  When a friend offered me a steak dinner, anywhere in Chicago, to say thanks for connecting him with what became his new job, I certainly had plenty of options. But having never been to Gibsons on Rush (though I've been to the one in Rosemont), it was my easy choice, over places I've been to (Chicago Chophouse, David Burke's, Morton's, Shula's, Ruths Chris) and others that I haven't (N9NE, The Capital Grille, Smith & Wollensky).  Did I make the best choice? Who knows, but I'm certainly not complaining. Having preferred a glass of white wine over red--seemingly the proper pick with steak--I'm certainly no gourmand. But while Gibson's has a reputation as a place for celebrity hobnobbing, predatory encounters and propositional interactions--of both the romantic and dealmaking sort--I was there for the food. Tiger Woods could've been with 3 hookers two tables over and I probably wouldn't have noticed.  So the ambiance was fine, if a bit crowded--even at 6:30 on a Monday--for my true preference. And the service was very good, except for a blunder I'll get to in a moment.  My Pinot Grigio was good. So was the bread, but of three varieties, the raisin bread was the clear keeper. A pair of appetizer oysters were fine, but nothing to write beyond this sentence about. The house salad with bleu cheese was nicely chilled and adequate in size, but more solid than spectacular. Even split in 2, the double-baked potato was huge and tasty. Now for the steak... We both ordered the W.R. Chicago Cut, a 21-ounce bone-in Rib Eye, Medium Rare, with my friend asking for his more on the rare side. Seemingly, that's the one I was served, for it was undercooked to my tastes. Certainly a quality steak, but not spectacular. After eating about half of it, as is, I had it sent back to the grill, and I imagine it was about Medium when I got it back. Much better, delicious and probably a 5-Star Steak if done right initially. But I didn't ever experience the "this is the greatest thing I've ever eaten" moment a truly extraordinary steak should give you.  The Chocolate Mousse Pie was huge, large enough likely for a table of 6, and far too much even for two food fanatics. But it was fantastic. Hard to go wrong there.  So all in all a good experience and I'm entirely happy with my selection and very appreciative of my friend's graciousness. But if I have a next occasion to go to a great Chicago steakhouse, I think I will try somewhere else before going back to Gibsons real soon.

some of the details escape my memory as i ate here quite awhile ago, but i do remember it being a carnivore's delight... if my memory serves me right i think this is the place that brings out a tray of meat and presents the different cuts... feast for the eyes entices the belly - a nice teaser of whats to come. i went for an early dinner (maybe 4ish?) in mid spring and it wasn't very crowded at that time - perhaps that was situational but i definitely enjoyed the open space, soft hummers of neighboring diners, and the attention of the wait-staff. i remember i had a tight schedule and had to be out of there in a relatively reasonable time; the waiter was very attentive to that need and i was very satisfied with the pace of the meal. i had the small filet mignon and split some sides; i dont remember which sides or their grande impressions (overall pleased) but i do remember being very satisfied with the option of a smaller cut of meat because i can get easily overwhelmed with the bigger cut. additionally this gave me better appreciation for the rest of the stuff i was gnoshing on. the only thing i wasn't impressed with was the decor, but i wasnt disappointed either; it didn't get in the way of my meal or enhance it. it is a classic steakhouse and i will more often than not find the photos of celebs kinda cheesy. id go back in a heartbeat while it was a quality experience.

Can you go to Chi and not go to Gibsons? It's not inventive food, but it is expected steakhouse fare, done flawlessly. It's always packed, so be ready to settle into the bar and be amused by the locals - they're there too.

We went tonight as we had heard from friends who live here that it was the best steak house in town.  We were not disappointed.  The Steak was excellent.  I had a Chicago cut medium rare and it was one of the most flavorful steaks I've eaten.  The atmosphere is definitely old school which it flaunts with great abandon.  Be prepared.  We liked that aspect.  The best part of the evening was our waiter, Mario,  who took the experience up another notch.  Informative without being pushy, attentive without being smarmy, he took the time to personalize our dining experience in a way that will make the evening celebrating my wife's birthday, most memorable.   And, no, we had never met Mario before and he is not my brother.   Though we did guess correctly that he is Peruvian.

really, the only reason i could see not 5 starring this would be that its pretty pricy.  ive been here at least 4 times now and the food, drink, and service are the best in chicago.  and the 4 times ive been are the once a year my dad comes into town and he pays! so i have 0 complaints whatsoever! nice!

A good, but not great, burger can be had here.  If it were just a little bit bigger, it would cross into great territory. The service here is fantastic.  Very solicitous.  Ditch the bathroom attendant, though; that's far too cheesy for a nice place like this. By the way, the decor here is very dated, somewhat spartan and not all that nice, in my opinion.  This is not a place to take a date or to impress a client (unless you know that your date or the client in question happens to like Gibsons).

gibsons is really the quintessential chicago steakhouse. to start off, the food is great. the standard steaks you get are big, cooked perfectly, and exactly what you expect to get. i'm a big fan of the bone-in ribeye (or ribeyes, in general). the sides are also quite large and perfect to share. potatoes done however you want, sauteed mushrooms, spinach creamed or sauteed, etc. and the wine selection is very broad and perfect for whatever you need. and if you get dessert, you get about 100x more than you could possibly finish. but somehow you finish it (through shear willpower... or lack thereof). suffice it to say, you will leave stuffed and satisfied. but what really really sets it apart from the handful of other steakhouses in the immediate v-triangle area is the service. you can tell they really take pride in how they conduct themselves towards patrons, whether you're a big-money type (honestly the majority of people you'll see here), or a meat-and-potatoes enthusiast. from my experience, the service is quick, knowledgeable and personable, and they'll make sure you'll have what you need, and try their best to get you what you want. the only knock i can think is that due to the normal clientele (the triangle, gold coast kind), it still is a bit intimidating and uncomfortable when you feel like everyone is judging. not gibsons fault, but just be prepared as always a great, old chicago kind of place though. i plan to be a regular
salmon was good. they advertise that its great corn fed beef. corn fed isnt something you want to advertise, is it? at any rate the service is great.

This place is impressive!  Tight at times to get around (bathroom, bar) , but the food is great and the service was top notch.  They undercooked my filet, brought out a whole new one and didn't charge for it.  Very unexpected, but it was a large bill so I know it was a small compensation for the amount, but almost unheard of anymore to do something like that.  Hugo Frog's is the same kitchen attached so if you can't get into Gibson's just eat there for the same food and same great atmosphere.  Probably the best cuts of meat around if you like steak!  Make a reservation or you might not get in until later in the evening.

I missed my homegirl's  birthday bash so I promised I would take her out for drinks to make up for it. She wanted to go to Gibson's so we strolled in there on a Monday night and she was shocked at how empty it was. I wasn't--it was a Monday night for Pete's sake! Besides us, there were probably 8 other people in the bar, but that didn't stop us from having a great time. We ordered up some cocktails and the good times started rolling! Another friend showed up and decided we needed champagne ( no, we didn't) and we basically shut the place down. The very gracious pianist extraordinaire, Lloyd took requests the rest of the night playing everything from Happy BIrthday to My Funny Valentine, a little Coltrane to my main man Miles Davis. We had a ball! Gibson's is still a scene and still overpriced but I always have a good time.

Love this place... having our rehearsal dinner here, the staff has been helpful ( a little on the young side), the service is usually amazing and the food is the best... no just a great steak but amazing side items and seafood.. I'm very happy we're having our rehearsal here!!

I have to say, I really like the way that the waiters come and present a huge tray filled with slabs of meat. The cuts are really impressive to look at, all next to each other on a serving tray. My favorite appetizer is the crab with avocado salad. Yum yum, just enough spice on the crab and nice slices of avocado to top it off. They cook the steaks perfectly--medium steaks that are not overcooked. The steaks are really so big that it's hard to fit in the sides as well. Now for dessert... they came out with a half-dome of ice cream topped with nuts and caramel. The ice cream came with its own steak knife. I would definitely return!

I live in Old Town and I do like the steaks here. BUT!!! The bartenders here "Fucking Suck!" On Tuesday the 9th I went in for a steak at the bar and left before I found myself kicking the shit out of the bartender. I don't care who you think you are or how good your steaks are. You are in the hospitality industry. If either of you fat boys need a lesson in Chicago hospitality I will be glad to give you a free clinic. I won't go back to Gibson's regardless of how close it is to my house. I have never had good service there and the only reason I have gone back is because the food is good. Not great. Good. There better steaks in Chicago. I wish every idiot that travels here would realize it and let this joke go under. And for the management: Shame on you for allowing this to happen. How could you not tell you have assholes for bartenders.

This is our favorate resturant in Chicago.  It's been a few years but the steaks blow you away.  And a very affordable wine list.   Greatany time of year.   Get a table by the window facing the triangle

I went here last night, and I swear it was the best filet mignon that I have ever tasted in my life. Medium rare, extremely tender, mouth-wateringly delicious. I didn't need any seasoning or sauce because it was just so flavorful. I also tried some of the lamb chops, which were equally tender and tasty. Sides for the table: spinach and mushroom, mashed potatoes. Appetizer: shrimp cocktail. Wine: Ruffino Chianti 2004 One of the best meals I have ever had. Luckily I didn't have to pay because it was definitely pricey. Amazing service, very polite staff. Free coat check up front. Pre-dinner drinks - pricey as expected but my screwdriver definitely had more vodka than orange juice. Yum! If you can afford it... Leftovers the next day for lunch were still delicious and tender :o]. What a treat!

My first steak house experience in Chi Town at Gibsons was superb!  Even on a Thursday evening this place bustles. Located in what is apparently called 'Viagra triangle' it is definitely a hot spot and a must try if you are ever in the Gold Coast neighborhood in Downtown. It was conveniently located across the street from my hotel so it was very accessible to visitors and tourists.  We had sidewalk dining which was elegantly displayed with surrounding plants, greens and flowers. Luckily, we were there early enough to avoid any wait as we were seated immediately. Evening dining out on the sidewalk is absolutely entertaining if you love to people watch like I do. I am a tourist to Chi Town so it was interesting to see the nightlife in another city. I did not see a lot of 'cougars' like some posted but I did observe a lot of older distinguished gentlemen conveniently posted outside in the patio tables with their cocktails and cigars scoping out the 'younger than them' crowd. That was entertainment enough for me!  The Small Filet Mignon with asparagus was divine cooked how I like..medium. The portions in anything you order is more than plentiful. I started off with a lobster bisque which I didn't want to stop spooning even after my Filet Mignon arrived. We also shared this ginormous Double Baked Potato which just melted in my mouth. However, my friend was not too impressed with their baked potato saying 'it's just an average potato'....oh no my friend...it is THE baked potato! It had all the fixins and was perfection.  Of course I always try and save room for dessert...even though I clearly did not have the room for it. I could not walk away dessert-less. What was absolutely fabulous is that my hotel gave me some coupons for some of the restaurants around the area. I had a coupon for a free dessert at Gibsons! No excuse now...so I ordered the magnanimous Chocolate Mousse Pie. Literally, this could have generously served 4 or 5 people. I have uploaded a picture of this chocolate mountain just to prove that I am not making this up..  I would rate Gibson's along with Ruth's Chris, Morton's, and Mastro's out in Southern Cali. Gibson's is on my list of reruns if I come back to Chi Town!

Everything that you think, want,  or imagine Gibsons to be, it IS! My whole experience from start to finish was excellent.  Our service was very attentive and not pushy which is nice when you want to enjoy your time. The steaks were cooked perfect and our server decided to bring us dessert for free.....hello:)  just know that the portions are huge so dessert might be hard to handle.

I go to Gibsons quite often, and love steaks. When I want a solid, predictable steak, this is where I go. The servings are huge, and the side dishes are a tasty addition here. I usually get the chicago cut, where the bone sort of wraps around the outside of the steak. The prime rib is also money with the horseradish. I always get my steaks medium rare, so depending on how you get your steak, it might be different than how I like it. When you go in, they'll bring out a plate that shows all the different cuts you can get, as well as a absolutely huge looking lobster tail. That said, I've had the giant lobster here, and I have to lower my rating because of this. It was sort of rubbery, and the taste wasn't what I expected. It was sort of dry, and I regretted ponying up the extra dough(quite expensive when compared to the steaks) to get this over my regular steak. I'd give the steaks a 4, and the lobster a 1.

The steak and the service here was amazing. I'd love to try the enormous lobster they brought out on the plate with the other cuts of meat.  (It was about the size of a catcher's mitt).  I had the Filet Oscar and it was delicious, but I'm pretty sure you can't go wrong here.  It was a meat market in every sense of the word.

I've been going to Gibsons for a few years now and I love the atmosphere and the food. I went there last night with a girlfriend of mine, and we asked for a table for the two of us and we got major attitude from the hostess. She was very rude, and not happy to see us for some reason. Really Gibsons? In this economy you should be greeting everyone with a smile at your door. Other than that, our server was great and we had the manager who was a very nice gentleman come over and check on us. We had the mahi mahi which was very good and then we also split the filet which we ordered med rare, but was more like medium. I will be back!

Just went back to Gibsons last Sunday and it has surpassed my last review (which was also good) I took my parents out for a nice Christmas/Anniversary dinner and we not only had impeccable service bu the food was amazing! The wine to die for! If you haven't been to Gibsons I gotta say GO!! And if you are lucky enough you'll get our server Elvis, he was the best!

**I would just like to note that I had a really hard time writing this review. As far as steaks go, this is the place to go. Friends and family of mine rave about how it is in their top five steakhouses. I am not a huge red meat craver but decided to try the pepper crusted fillet. It was the spiciest piece of meat I have ever had. They aren't kidding when they say it is hot.  I also ordered mine medium-well. My mother ordered hers medium and my father medium-rare. They all came out with the same amount of pink (it was more of a blood red, really). My big problem with this restaurant is how they jam pack you in like sardines. The last time we went there our table was squeezed in so tightly between two other tables that there was no way I could get up to use the restroom. I had two wait 30 minutes for one of the tables to get up. In the five minutes it took me to use the restroom and come back they had already seated the other table. I couldn't have gotten back to my seat with out having to make three other people get up. So what did I do? I stood by the table while we paid the bill. It took over 15 minutes to settle up and it wasn't even our server who ran our credit card.  ***I used to be a server and am pretty good about knowing when your server is terrible or if he is just in the weeds and a mark of an excellent server is how quickly the check is settled. *** The time before that when we came here, our table was so close to the host stand that people that were waiting for their table were practically sitting in our laps. I don't know how many times I got hit with a coat.  Anyway, back to the most recent time. Our server was friendly but absent minded. He forgot a glass of wine and didn't remember it until we were finished eating. He offered to buy us a dessert, but after all the meat I don't know how anyone could have room. I had a cup of jambalaya that was really good and for the table we ordered a side of the mushrooms and a baked potato (for my brother). The mushrooms were great and the potato a little dry.  This place has so much potential!! It pains me to say all these negative things, but I have to be honest. They need to stop cramming people in. The bar is almost impossible to walk through and you must have a reservation. I get that they are trying to make money but it has to be more that just good food. It has to be a great all over experience.

I am a steak lover. Steak is my passion. Every time I travel I try to find the best steak house in town and try it out. Gibson's has the best steak I have ever eaten, anywhere in the world. The service at Gibson's is out of this world. I cannot compliment Gibson's enough. This is my favorite restaurant in the world. Make sure to try the ribeye, and you will not be disappointed. Make sure you are hungry when you go, because the portions are fit for a king. Everything at Gibson's is perfect. From the excellent drinks, to the incredible food, the comfortable ambiance, to the attendant in the bathroom waiting for you to finish washing your hands with a towel ready. A+++!

I've went to Gibsons last night and I have eaten there a couple times.  Being from Chicago, I've been to a lot of the steakhouses and this place has to be the most overrated by far.  I don't get it.  The steaks are good, not great.  The service is excellent but the food just isn't that great, especially for those ridiculous prices.  I know the steaks are Prime but they just don't have that much flavor.  They are now offering crusted toppings like horseradish crusted NY strip which is what I got but the horeradish was pretty much just laid on top.  It wasn't bad, just not something I would go back for or get a craving for.  Too bland.    That said, the avocado crab meat appetizer and salad were good and the dessert was good.

I had a reservation. Brought to a table. The waiter and wait staff all seemed tense and uncomfortable. Our waiter's voice was cracking as he described the main dishes. He went on after bringing our drinks to recite accolades, some religious incantations to my wife. I said, jokingly, one more and we will leave. The man grabbed my thumb and wouldn't let go. I tried to shake my hand free but he held on and went on his delirious way. When he was safely away from the table, we left. We walked half a block to the original Arnie Morton's and had a great, but very expensive dinner. I suspect Gibson's is for amateurs. Avoid. I called twice from Morton's, but not body cared about what had happened.

So it was my husbands birthday he suggested Gibsons because the last time we had steak from there it was like butter, granted that was nine years ago but for a restaunt with this kind of reputation and longevity it sucked!!!! First of all we made reservations and still waited half an hour.  Then after being bumped and pushed by all the important people in the crowded lobby we got seated. You guessed it, we were the nicely dressed Latino couple you sat by the kitchen for the money you pay at this place there should be no bad tables especically one to make you feel so insignificant, so typical.  I mean my husband wore a suit for this?!  A draft above us, the coming and going of the waitstaff, the fact that the table was too small for more than two plates. That's not the worst of it. The food was sub par!   I have had better steak at Wildfire, Lwoods even Longhorn and didn't pay $200 dollars that's right 2 "dry" steaks with salad, drinks, 1 helpng of overly garliced mashed potatoes add tip, valet and coatcheck and I was out $200 bucks.  In this economy!!! This place is overrated, overpriced, loud, and stuffed with stuffy patrons. I wasted my Christmas bonus for this?  I will never ever go back again!!!!!

My father was in town for business this past week, and we thought it was a fitting occasion to go out and grab a steak.   After having two more different cuts, (i had the porterhouse he had the w.r. chicago cut but we each cut a portion for one another since there is PLENTY)  I've decided that while the steaks are very good, better steaks can be had else where. The kick just wasn't quite there in the steaks.  They were very good but the seasoning just wasn't what could have been.  It's a classic place that you have to take in, but if Gibson's wants to be the best there is a little work to be done.   When I go back I'll have to have the filet with one of the fancy things on top (i saw blue cheese covering our neighboring tables filtets, why didn't my waiter mention this to us? hmm)  and one of the massive baked potatoes.

A reliable stalwart.  This legendary steak house has it all.  Great food and soul.  Steaks are always superb, the servers are characters and the head steak guy who comes to the table, tosses down a porterhouse and says "this is meat" is a legend.  This place is unique and part of the fabric of Chicago.

Best  steak next to Del Friscos, not sure which is better.  I had the fillet med. rare and it was like buttah!  So delicious.  Service was also great.  Highly highly recommend this steak house when visiting Chi.  Only down side... no good champagnes or sparklings by the glass.  Since I was the only one who wanted it, buying a full bottle of Veuve at $150 was too risky and pricey.  i would have to force myself (who am I kidding?!) to drink the whole bottle at that price.

Gibsons is almost always a good choice, unless you're not in the mood for Viagra Triangle's finest selection of wealthy older men, cougars and Eastern-European girls dressed like prostitutes.  As long as you sit at a table, you should be able to avoid this.  Speaking of getting a table, make a reservation.  This place is ALWAYS busy and there is usually a wait. However- the wait is worth it.  The service is great and the food is classically delicious.  I highly recommend the shrimp cocktail (collosal) and the filet with mashed potatoes, sauteed mushrooms or creamed spinach.  Everything is fabulous and majorly hits the comfort spot.  You may be in pain afterwards, though. Drinks are great too, solid wine list.   Gibsons is just good.

When you order the prime rib and the waitress looks at you like you've been smoking crack right at  the table, don't ignore her.  And when she says "um... it's REALLY big, like, REALLY, are you sure?" she is not kidding.  I don't even think to call what landed in front of me massive would do it justice.  But it was 33 oz of meaty juicy goodness, perfectly cooked.  If I lived in town I would have had leftovers for about a week.  Well worth it!  Wine list had a great selection and the apple pie, mmm mmm mmm.

I haven't experienced a dinner so great in ages! The staff was incredible and the food .. muah! I had the filet and split a double baked potato. I think I could have that potato over and over and never get tired of it. I think this place is fun for special occasions - birthday, anniversary, etc. but probably a bit much for a drop by bite.

As most people would expect, the food here is really phenomenal. Started it off with the shrimp cocktail, with gigantic shrimp and a pretty spicy cocktail sauce I liked.  Next came the salad, which had a really nice dressing.  The filet and scalloped potatoes were both great, and I had no complaints.  I'd say Morton's has a better filet, but its hard to really judge meals that were months apart from one another. Definitely recommend either if you're in town.

Best steak ever eaten in my life. Full stop.  I have been here three times since I moved to Chicago, and each time was better than the previous one. Seriously, there is nothing below excellence for this restaurant: top notch service, excellent steaks, nice atmosphere.  Mmm, I am mouth watering even now, typing these words thinking of their porterhouse...

Good food, but quite frankly a little over rated in my opinion.  I was expecting a blow the doors off, knock your socks off, fantastic meal!  I place Gibson's slightly above Morton's in terms of quality and flavor.  Don't get my wrong, the food was good.  But, it certainly did not live up to the hype.  I really don't understand the long wait for a table.  Granted, the location is money sitting right in the smack center of Rush St.  I had the WR Chicago Cut, which is basically a bone-in ribeye. This was the most highly recommended entrée on the menu by our waitress that she was creamin' over.  With that kind of enthusiasm, I was sold!  Again, it was good... but certainly did not live up to the hype and that said, over-priced!  Apps were good.  Service was excellent!

So I had a friend recommend that I take my family here for a traditional Chicago dinner. We had 6:00 reservations and showed up a couple minutes early. They claimed they had 6:30 reservations and ended up sitting us around 6:40. This is unacceptable when your dropping some serious coin on a piece of meat. Although I must admit, the food and the service was very good and made up for making me wait 40 min.

While the service was good, my steak was extremely disappointing. I ordered a medium-cooked steak and it was delivered to the table raw. The waitress sent it back to be refired. Within five minutes the plate returned with the meat unchanged. The manager sent the steak back and ten minutes later it returned cooked beyond medium, to a well-done state: grey to the center, void of all juices, and as chewy as leather. The meat was inedible. Everyone speaks enthusiastically about Gibsons steaks, but I left Gibsons hungry.

sat at a table in the bar area so we could catch game 6. it was pretty crowded, but we made due. we were originally seated at a fairly cramped table, but our waitress, lacey, kept an eye out for a bigger table. we happened to score one a few minutes after getting our first round of drinks - score one for accommodating service. dinner went something like this:  appetizers:  crab meat avocado  oysters  salad  entree:  small filet  creamed spinach  mashed potatoes & gravy  the oysters were nice and big, and fresh. the crab meat dish was good, but seemed to be overpowered by both the avocado and the dressing the salad was prepared with.  the steak came out perfectly cooked - medium rare - and was served with a side bearnaise sauce. totally unnecessary since the steaks were perfectly seasoned and nicely charred, but a nice little bonus. i recently found out i'm a creamed spinach fan (who knew?) and the side at gibson's is not to be ignored - dee-lish! as for the mashed potatoes, they were just ehh. maybe it's because i'm a mashed potato snob, but i wished we would have ordered for another side. the gravy didn't make them any better either.  overall, we had a great meal. we were well taken care of by our waitress, the drinks were great and the ambiance has still got that old school charm (people were seated around the piano, drinking, while the pianist played away - how cool is that?) there's a reason why it's a chicago standard; last night, it lived up to it's name for me.

Excellent special Occassion restaurant.   Highest quality food, extra attentive and professional service.   Ask for Server Jeannie - she is the best.   She watched over us just like Mom, keeping us happy from start to finish!   She noticed we made short work of our delicious split pea soup and offered to bring us more.  She was on top of every detail and you could tell she  took pleasure in a job well done.  Don't forget the turtle ice cream cake.  About halfway through dessert, Jeannie brought us some back up bowls of hot fudge and hot caramel.   Heaven.

I came here last night 11/3, and had a wonderful meal. We ordered a seafood tray with shrimp, scallops, oysters, crab, and spicy lobster. It was fantastic. We had two great bottles of cab, and the salad was great but had a little too much salad dressing. But my main dish, I ordered a skirt steak, which is my favorite steak, and mashed potatoes. George was our server and he was excellent.

I was here once before in 2005 and I loved it.  So coming back to chicago on biz 4 years later, I am an older guy, so I kinda have to visit the viagra triangle now.  We wanted a place that was a high end steakhouse where we can watch the Yanks in the series, and while most steakhouses we checked out were either bar/grill kinda places, or there were no TVs in the dining area.  Gibsons gave us both.  Since we came after a few bars and planned to continue on drinking afterwards, we didnt really mess around with sides.  Just 4 steaks, 4 glasses of red wine, and on our way. Service was very friendly and attentive.  2 guys ordered the bone in rib eye which they said was amazing, and two ordered filet.  I had the fliet and it was possibly the best one I have ever had.  The meat was cooked perfectly, charred on the outside, and pink in the middle.  The wine they suggested also went really well with the steak.  Although I want to try out some of the other great steakhouses in chicago when I come back, I'll probably just head straight to Gibsons!

My husband and I both ordered lobster tail and they were both dry.  It is very likely because it was Australian lobster and probably was pre-frozen.  I should know better to eat only Maine lobster, because it's sweeter and more likely fresh due accessibility to it.  The bar area is good for the middle-aged trying to hook up with other people or business people taking out client for a nice dinner, but I think the place is way over-rated.  Many people buy into a place because it's "the place to be", but that's not good enough for me -- I need good food.  If anything, it's a good place to have a drink and the bartender Mark is cool guy.  He said to come back after we finished our dinner and he'd make me a chocolate martini on the house.  He kept his promise and it was a really good martini.

Gibson's is a very good Steakhouse in the Gold Coast area in Chicago.  Their cuts of meat are generous and delicious, although they char the outside of the steak, which is not my favorite preparation style.  The appetizers are tasty and generous, enough to share with two or three people.  The desserts are enough to feed 6 people. You can't even come to grips with how large they are until you see them. My favorite is the chocolate mousse pie, but I am told the carrot cake is delicious as well.  The ambiance is good for a lunch or dinner business meeting, dinner with friends or romantic dinner. The staff are attentive and friendly.

My first visit to Gibson's on a recent business trip to Chicago last week was terrific. We had a reservation at 8:30 p.m., checked in at the hostess stand, and were eventually seated a little after 9 p.m. We chatted with the hostess about the delay, and she graciously got us all a comp drink from the bar and sent a great crab/avocado appetizer to our table. Great first impression! Since we were on the late side, I couldn't handle eating one of the great steaks (my co-workers all really enjoyed theirs), so I ordered the prime rib French dip -- excellent! The meat was really delicious, as was the grilled bread and plentiful fries. Shared some creamed spinach, which was good but not outstanding. I started with a wedge salad - delicious blue cheese dressing. Of course, we ordered a slab of carrot cake to share. It's dense and really heavy, so a small slice does the trick. Next time, I'd try the chocolate. Service was good, and although it seemed like it took  for.ev.er . to order, the food delivery was timed right.

I try not to eat steak much, but if i do, I would want it to be at Gibsons. I guess they call this a classic Chicago steakhouse--looks like any other steakhouse to me. I wasn't in the mood for their gigantic house ribeye, so i opted for the big filet.  Medium-rare goodness.Double baked potato was as smooth as the sour cream and cheese smothered over it--or maybe that was just the sour cream.  Nevertheless, be sure to get their veggie combo-- a whole head of broccoli, asparagus, spinach, and these amazing mushrooms packed with umami flavor.

Gibson's is one of the classic, premier Chicago steakhouses.  They are usually splendid, and when they do misfire, they'll make it right so long as you bring it to their attention.  The old, dark hardwoods, the lingering of decades of background cigar smoke, and the power diners all around you give you a sense of that true "old boys club" ambiance that defined great steakhouses in the mid-20th century. For lunch, drop in and have the filet sliders - delicious, and you can order individually (after the first 3 which come together).  That and a few oysters or shrimp cocktail plus a half salad or small bowl of soup is a huge, decadent, lovely midday self-treat. Note that Hugo's Frog Bar is fully connected with Gibson's, If memory serves, you can get anything from the Gibson's dinner menu at Hugo's for dinner, but there are some things Gibson's won't vend from the Hugo's menu - odd, huh? So if the meat is wonderful, the choices classic and great (if not plentiful), what's the downside?  Answer: cost.  Gibson's is even expensive for a steakhouse.  While I loved dropping in for lunch, what I described earlier would easily set me back $50 or more - not a cheap treat, and that's on the lunch menu.  Dinner hits easily for $80, and that's without being indulgent or getting sides - go to a full shrimp cocktail and either a good-sized, luscious lobster tail or a really big, decadent cut of steak, and you're going higher still. So they priced themselves out of being a daily - or even weekly - event for most people.  Go when you want a rich sensory experience that's every bit as much a pamper as a Vosges chocolate run.  Just be sure to dress up a little before you go so they take you seriously. This earns 4.5 stars without blinking, and when they're on, they're 5 star - a classic Chicago "king of steak" steakhouse.
Put on your blue sports coat with the gold buttons and your captains' hat and GO! Atmosphere: classic steakhouse Service: spotless  Food: the steaks are the best in town!

When my buddy asked if we were having a "bigboy" dinner on my visit to Chicago, it seemed like a no brainer. I said lets go steak since it's the midwest, you guys have no shortage of cattle, and when in Rome.... He booked us a 7pm Fri night rese at Gibson's, which I thought was a tad early, but he assured me even though we had the rese, we might still have to wait and dining here is usually close to a 2 hr affair. He was spot on and after arriving we waited 15 before being sat. The place was packed, which he said is normal 7 days a week. The inside of this space is old-school which I prefer over the new sleek steak spots. It reminded me of some of the places my folks used to take me in Philly and Jersey when I was a kid. Our waiter was awesome, spitting out funny 1 liners he's probably said a thousand times before, but super attentive, snappy, and cool. He brought out the plate to show us the different cuts and the largest flippin lobster tail I have ever seen.  I went with the DW specialty which was a rib-eye and although I ran into a few sinewy moments, it was unbelievably bursting with flavor. For sides we split a 1/2 order of garlic and lemon spinach w/ whole button mushrooms, and 1 twice baked potato. I originally wanted nothing to do with the potato when I saw one at the table near us. Then the waiter described it's preparation: baked once, scooped and pureed with herbs and spices, re-stuffed, doused in cheddar and baked again. It was crazy good, both soft and crunchy, creamy and cheesy,  and I had to stop myself from finishing it so I'd be able to go out after dinner.  When our steaks arrived, which we had both ordered medim-rare,  I cut into mine and felt it both looked and tasted medium. I'm usually not one to send something back, but when you're dropping over $40 on 1 dish, it's gotta be the way you want it. Our waiter didn't even second guess us or make a face, he promised he would take care of it right away and less then 10 mins later, we had 2 brand new steaming steaks in front of us, cooked to perfection. He apologized endlessly and before bringing the check at the end, he comped us an apple pie a la mode. Neither one of us had any room for it whatsoever, but it was a nice gesture.  To top it off my bud picked up the check and treated for my bday, what a badass! Thanks Peeps! I'd def suggest Gibson's to anyone traveling to Chicago or if you haven't made it here yet. One more final note: extra props to Gibson's for not jumping on the 5 different types of sauces to drown your steak in bandwagon seen way too often at upscale steak joints. Do you want to taste steak, or a mayo-ey blend of peppercorn and cheesy bullshit? Keep your sauces and I'll stick with a well seasoned steak.  1 more tip: The restaurant right next door called something Frog, is owned by and shares the same kitchen with Gibson's. If you are dying for a Gibson's steak and can't get a reservation, you can go here and order the steak, same quality, same price. That's a bingo!
Better than good steaks....sides are lacking...was looking forward to Gibson's.  Great service and vibe.

I know I'm going to be in the minority but this was my experience at the famous Gibson's. Ordered the New York Strip. I always ask at a restaurant how the Chef would like it served. They said medium. OK, no problem.  We wait 45 minutes while getting polite refills and appetizers. I am brought the blackest, most charred steak I've ever touched. I took one bite and sent it back saying it was burnt. The interior wasn't even pink.  My second steak was no better. So after an hour and a half I had not eaten dinner and had nothing to show for it. For being famous for steaks, they didn't seem to know what was going on. Maybe it was a bad Sous Chef or something but I won't be going back if the one thing they are supposed to be experts at, they failed at making.

I'm not as carnivorous as your average bear, but I still enjoyed eating here. My husband looooves steak, and I'll gladly abandon mine for the sides if they are delicious. That is exactly what happened here. My recommendation: unless you love love steak, don't waste the time (or the stomach space). Ignore the weird looks your waiter will give you and just order a HUGE twice baked potato. Put it in the center of the table, and roll around in it. I did...

Filet Mignon with a side of asparagus was exceptional. Perfect slightly dirty martiinis. Great service, good blend of outdoor/indoor seating. Of the higher end chain restaurants, I'd definitely come back to Gibsons.

I was very excited to eat at Gibsons (and secretly hoping to see someone famous)!  While I didn't see anyone famous, I was not disappointed.  I tried their bone-in filet mignon and ribeye steaks, which were moist and cooked to perfection.  We also ordered their oyster selection, which was fresh and lovely.  They have great french fries and a gigantic slice of sweet and decadent ice cream cake if you still have room in your stomach!  Gibsons is a Chicago institution and I definitely will go back.

You know, I've heard a lot of good things about this place, but had never been in there.  I was REALLY hungry at 4:30 one night not too long ago, so I went by myself to get a steak. I ended up getting just a regular 14 ounce Filet Mignon medium rare.  The steak itself was really good, pretty much exactly how i like it cooked.  With some raw horseradish, it's very good.  Probably not THE best steak I've ever had, but definitely in the top 5 or 7 steaks I've had. Also had some Malbec wine with it which went pretty well.  What I found funny was how they ID'd me when I ordered the wine.  I thought "Why would an underage kid come into a semi-pricey steakhouse by himself, order a $40 steak, and then risk ordering a glass of wine?"  Was just funny. Anyway, overall great steak!

These guys specialize in steak and they are experts in their trade.  I like it when steak houses actually bring out the raw meat and show you the cuts so you can decide for yourself what looks best.  I decided on the porterhouse with light peppercorn crust and light fresh garlic.  Delicious, although the steak had a bit more connective tissue than I would normally expect for a place of this caliber, so there's no way I can give it 5 stars.

The atmosphere: Old school Chicago charm. The waiters are "seasoned" in a good way. They make you feel important and like your meal and experience is the most important thing about their night.  To start: The bread is amazing. The dressing on the salads is homemade and the best there is. I love the ranch.  The food: I love the steaks, love the salmon, love it all.  The sides: The brocolli, the asparagus, etc. all good. THE DOUBLE baked potato is a spectacle. It's so good, sometimes I feel like the potato could be cooked a little more, but I know it probably would take days to get a potato that size well-done. The deserts: perfection Tips: Make sure to have everyone order their own entree, but just get a few sides to share. The huge potato can definitely serve four of my friends as a side, and the vegetables as well. I highly recommend sitting in the bar and listening to the piano player. It makes me feel about 10-40 years older than I am...but I just love it!
This is a meat market - but not the type where you find a good steak if you catch my drift.  Over-priced.

One of the premier steakhouses in Chicago with good reason - it's simple, no nonsense steak. First off, make sure you plan ahead put down a reservation. Otherwise you might be waiting for a while. This place seems to always be buzzing with diners! The setting is beautiful, classy, yet keeping it all very simple. The dining atmosphere plus the classy setting equals a terrific experience. The food and service was terrific. The waitress was very polite and accommodating. The Prime Rib was good. I also tried the whole roasted chicken and skirt steak, and both are very good also. The food presentation was simple and straightforward...just the way I like it at steakhouses.

It doesn't matter if you are a disbarred lawyer serving probation or just a crooked politician with a wire tap, Gibsons has still got it.  Who cares if it is crowded, the hostess has an attitude, you are so stupid that you come to this palace without a reservation, it is still great.  Personally I'm a vegetarian, not. Some damn good meat and I don't mean the trophy wives and girlfriends. Cougar watch, stay away from the high maintenance Dennis R. Surf and Turf, baby!  Shiat, a tad better than that Angus at Mickey D's with theirs aged over a month. Hell, concrete cures faster. Peppercorn, did you say peppercorn?

Steakhouses are my thing. I've eaten at Mortons, Capital Grille, Ruths Chris, Ajasteak, David Burke's, Eli's, Chop House and many more. But Gibsons is my favorite Chicago Steakhouse!! I'm a little sad to see that they have taken my fave steak off the menu.  It was the Wagyu Prime Rib.  It was the best piece of meat ever - it was like a pad of butter in my mouth with the best seasoning you've ever had.   The filet is always my gold standard at any steak house.  The filet at Gibsons is wonderful as well.  Perfectly cooked, well seasoned. All around satisfying and delish.  I love when the waiter brings the raw cuts of meat to the table to show you! Love it love it love it.

I am giving Gibson's the nod as my favorite Chicago Steakhouse... the atmosphere is awesome, the staff is great, and its where the celebrities flock to for a steak when they are in Chicago. Everything here is perfectly done, and the bartenders make great dirty martini's.  If your not sure about dropping the cash to try it, go to lunch here, it is heavily discounted.  I would take any visitor I had to Gibson's if they came to Chicago looking for a classic steakhouse and I would tell anyone reading this review to do the same.

mmmmmmeat.   This is a great place and the one I would suggest to any visitor.  First, it's a scene.  Fun locale for people watching.  Second, the service is spunky and fun.  Third, steak.  MMM.  Fourth, save room for the humongous slice of cake for dessert.

Gibsons is one of my favorite places in town, great food, great service, and an awesome atmosphere.   To some of the other reviewers talking about how it's too crowded and that they had to wait long, what do you expect?  You're going to the one of the most popular spots in one of the hottest areas in the city.  If you roll in on a Friday evening, it's going to be crowded. I prefer to go to Gibsons for a late lunch/early dinner in the afternoon, sit in the classic old school bar and enjoy the afternoon and enjoy the day with any of their great steaks, or a fantastic sandwhich.  Their BLT is one of the best I've ever had.  What's better on a nice Saturday afternoon than a martini, a lobster salad, and a BLT? The steaks at Gibsons are excellent, and classically prepared.  They're not the absolute best in the city (Harry Carays, Capital Grille, and David Burke's Primehouse come to mind) but certainly in the top half dozen or so, and the great service and atmosphere puts Gibsons right up there with my favorite places in the city.

I went here for dinner on a Friday evening with some co-workers... Walking in, the place was absolutely packed.  We had a party of 15 or 16 and reservations, but we ended up waiting for what must have been an hour+.  We crammed into the bar, standing in the aisle right at the entrance and most likely causing a fire hazard.  It was definitely loud - If you weren't standing next to me, I would barely hear you.   Despite the unfortunate beginning, I had a great evening with my co-workers because, well, we're a fun group.  People have complained (it seems) about the display of steak cuts and seafood that they show to every table.  We didn't have any problems (no raw meat juice flowing all over etc...) but as I said, none of us really understood anything the waiter said.  We ordered a one lobster tail for the 6 of us to share and each got our own steaks - our version of surf n turf.  You should go here to try the steak.  I got the rib-eye which was delicious.  It was absolutely amazing - best steak I've had.  Cooked well, seasoned well.  This place would definitely be 5 stars if they put the rest of their act together.  It is expensive, and it is definitely loud, but when you're eating you kind of forget all of that.   The crowd is definitely the epitome of the "Viagra Triangle".  It was primarily filled w/ young to middle-age professionals who wanted to act rich and powerful.  I feel bad for the wives of some of these men who think it's okay to go out and take off their ring or for the future wives of some men who don't seem to have matured much from their college days.   All in all, I had really wonderful food.  If you have really excellent company and a whole evening to waste, then come here for sure.

Ahhh, Gibsons. Where have you been all my life?! As an earlier reviewer mentioned, you can get a good steak in a lot of places. (Gibsons is definitely one of those places, by the way, no matter what else you read here on Yelp -- the W.R.'s Chicago Cut is by far one of the best cuts of marbled steak I've had anywhere. My husband's filet was pretty darned great, too.) But, as said reviewer also stated, what sets Gibsons apart from the rest of those restaurants is that they completely spoil you here. Our waiter comped us a chocolate mousse cake for no reason other than (his words) we were such nice people. Call it brown-nosing if you like, but I haven't received a compliment like that at Chop House or Morton's. Again, great food, excellent service. What else could you ask for in a fine-dining experience?

Came here from a recommendation, since Chicago is known for their steaks. We were able to make a last min 9pm reservation which when we got there was still REALLY packed. The surrounding area around the restaurant is actually very lively! We were seated almost immediately, and got great seats at the window of the restaurant so it was a lot quieter than sitting inside. We were given bread and butter - and it comes with 3 different types of bread - my favorite was the one with all the nuts in it. Yum! The cool thing about this place is that the waiter came out with a whole tray of raw steaks and one lobster tail. Just to show us the steak and explain the cuts to us. Very cool. I ordered the small sirloin, since the regular sized sirloin looked really big. We also decided to share the twice baked potato amongst the three of us. Even my small steak was pretty big - and rare just like I wanted. The waiter did tell us that the meat is normally a bit rarely than what it normally is. So when I ordered rare, he did tell me it'd be pretty rare. I told him to bring it on, the bloodier the better! The steak itself was very juice and tender. Crispy on the outside, and juicy on the inside. My friends ordered the filet mignon and the classic cut and said that was excellent as well. I was so full from my "small" steak that I could barely finish the 1/3 of the twice baked potato!  We were going to order dessert, when we saw that the table next to us ordered a dessert - and it was huge! One dessert could easily feed 4 people! Too stuffed for me. The bathroom is upstairs - and they have a bathroom tenant working there. Overall, great steak. Service was excellent here, our waiter was wonderful. Def. a must try if you are looking for some great steak in Chicago.

This place had the most delicious, melt in your mouth, tender cuts of beef around! The staff is awesome & always there with whatever you want or need, the food is exceptionally delicious, and the atmosphere is upbeat. Definitely the best steak house I have been to ion Chicago. Try the meaning of life cake & there peppercorn tenderloin or even the cobb salad.

My note to the snooty hostess: If I wasn't eating here and working at the front door of a restaurant before you were born, then certainly before you were .... a lady. Listen, girl: all the people like me who come in with no reservation already know it's likely that the wait will be long, if not an hour, as it was last night. We don't need no stinking perjorative eye roll from a 20-something punk like you. The really nice part: I ran into a judge who had been my favorite law professor. He was there with his son. It was really nice to see him and catch up. But Gibsons: it's okay to hire classy people.

On the evening news, they love talking about how Johnny Depp or Leonardo DiCaprio went here for dinner. It makes me feel like crying. This is NOT the best steakhouse in Chicago. Not by a long shot. First of all, the food here is average at best. If you don't order steak, expect it to be mediocre, and leave you with a horrible guilty feeling in your stomach to boot, knowing that even if you take home the massive doggie bag they'll give you, some poor starving child or family could've really eaten that food AND you're going to throw it all away in 10 lbs of paper and plastic that they wrap it up in after it languishes in your fridge for days. The one bright side is that for $15, you get the most massive, heart-attack inducing carrot cake invented. I don't care if it's not totally amazing. Your whole table can share it and you don't have to leave pissed off that your boyfriend (who promised only to have "one bite) ate the whole thing--cause there's going to be enough left over for you to be eating it for 3 days. Don't even get me started on the wine list. Talk about cliched, corporate, grocery store brands that are marked up an insane amount. They pour jug wine as their by the glass house wine and charge $9. Highway robbery! Finally, much to my surprise (or not, given the neighborhood it's in and the clientele this place serves), there were hookers in the bathroom. Hookers! Talking about what kind of night they were having so far, and who they were pulling in from the bar--a bunch of silver fox douchebag types that think they're hot shit because they are with 22-year-old call girls. Come to think of it, maybe that IS why all of Hollywood's Romeos come here... The one shining thing about this place is the service--it's exceptional. I would give it 5 stars--the servers are professional, know the menu and the wines, and are funny and helpful. Whoever trains them does an amazing job. If you must come here, come early, order dessert and definitely don't linger at the bar... And always ask your server for any hidden gems on the wine list!

Came here on a trip to Chicago at the rec of a few people.  We had a reservation, but still had to wait about 20 mins, but no big deal!  The decor is still trapped in the late 80s.  While we enjoyed the meal thoroughly, it wasn't all I would expect for being in the heart of meat country USA.  I ordered my steak medium to medium well, and it came out medium to medium rare- while it was still delicious, the server never even came back to ask how things were.  For sides we got broccoli and a baked potato (my boyfriend's choice).  The baked potato was just an overpriced baked potato, but I loved the broccoli.  The martinis here are STRONG.  I had two and during a large meal and I felt really good!  Haha.

My meat-and-potatoes Nordstrom-wearing boyfriend loves this place more than me. We ate here back in January so my memory escapes me a bit.  Food: I typically eat prime rib, but was convinced to try the *filet mignon medium and it wasn't anything special. He ate *something huge and medium-rare, I'm sure. He loved it. I ordered the *Frei Brothers Merlot because... I know my wine. It didn't disappoint. Some people seem to think a rare or medium-rare steak shouldn't be charred or crisp at all. This mystifies me. I think the fat should be crisp just a bit, no matter to what amount the steak is cooked inside. Gibson's didn't disappoint in regards to being cooked correctly for us. I did have a hell of a *martini beforehand and may have just been happy to eat anything. We also had the *mashed potatoes which were nice... like mom's. I believe I ate a whole lot of *bread too, but I'm not very discriminating with bread. Conclusion: It was alright, but we won't go back on my dime (not that we did this time either!). I'll get the prime rib next time- stay in my forte. I'm looking forward to trying the Chicago Chophouse. I heard they do the dry rub, which I prefer. I want to learn more about expensive/good steaks and know Chicago is a great place for it. Service: Our waiter was an older black man with a pretty good sense of humor. He told us a little of the "who's who" at tables and whatnot... I didn't even realize that was why people came... to celebrity-ish site see. He wasn't horribly attentive, but the boyfriend thought his personality was just incredible. Again, he would leave me for this restaurant if forced to choose.

The food is fabulous but the  service strikes out: they're usually slow and ignorant.  Twice I've had great service: once from Nick and once from Alexandra, but otherwise lousy. The outdoor patios is recommended; inside the place looks like the same designer for Outback Steak House got the Gibson's contract. Go to Rosebud on Walton instead: outstanding food, impeccable service.

I have to admit the steak was good.  Not the best I've ever had or quite worth the price tag, but you don't really come to this place for the food.  You come to see the Aston Martins and Lambos parked out front.  I even saw a Bugati roll up the other day.  I didn't run into the mayor or my alderman, so I was a little disappointed.

When I heard that Johnny Depp liked this place, I wanted to check it out. I am from out of town and indeed I was impressed. I ordered the Chicago cut, fries, asparagus. Everything was very impressive and the waiter made me feel at home. The steak was cooked properly and I really couldn't have asked for anything else. I was even impressed when I went to the bathroom and they had Michael Jackson playing!

The husband took me here for my birthday, and I was really looking forward to it. The waiter was an ass, however. He laughed at me when I ordered a porter house asking me twice if I was sure that's what I wanted. Twice the wrong wine was brought to our table. When the steaks finally came out it was burnt on the outside. A medium rare steak should not be crispy anywhere. I would have sent it back, but the waiter didn't come around for about 20 minutes. I would not go back here or recommend it to anyone. There are a ton of steak houses in this city that don't suck. Try one of them.

Admittedly, its been over 5 years since I've been to Gibsons.  But I will always remember the lobster I had.  It was a HUGE catch and cost about $100 dollars, but it was the first time in my life I loved lobster.  I've been hooked ever since.

Once you get past the stink of the viagra triangle, this place has a lot to offer. Every piece of meat that we ordered was world class. The Filet mignon was probably the best of them all. Leftovers lasted longer than Thanksgiving dinner. I will be back to replenish my iron intake.  Some downsides: Side dishes are very disappointing and while I liked the waiter he needed to know when to turn it down a notch. My dad went from being amused by him to wanting to punch him in the face. But maybe we didn't get that it's part of the schtick of this place - I'll give them the benefit of the doubt.

I've had the good fortune of eating more than my fair share of steak. Texans tend to eat more dead cow, on average, and being Texans, we have loud, obnoxious debates about where to find the best steaks.  I would gladly defend Gibson's steakhouse in any argument.  I don't anticipate this review adding anything to the many that have come before, but some meals are so good you feel compelled to relive the experience with a postgame breakdown.  The steak was top notch, creme de la creme, and numerous other cliches.  I honestly do not care about the sides, the salad, or the desert.  I guess to those who value the food pyramid those things are important, but this was all about the steak.  They don't bring around a platter of broccoli and carrots for a reason.  It's an afterthought.  If I'm reviewing the other stuff I probably say 4 stars,  but this is like watching the Cavaliers - you don't really care about Anderson Varejao, you're there for Lebron, no other reason.  I had the filet, it was amazing, and I would do it again tomorrow if I didn't live in Dallas.

I live right around the corner from this amazing Steak House.  I have never had a bad meal here.  You can sit outside on the sidewalk when it is warm.  If you are not up for waiting for a table, grab a seat in the bar, it first come first serve. You must go with the Turtle Pie if you like the most amazing dessert around!   Request Mo as your waiter if you want to have another great experience, not always the easiest guy to get, but worth the wait.

The most noteworthy difference between Gibson's and the other local steakhouses? Gibson's SPOILS their customers. Every staff member is trained as an eager-to-please service master. In honor of their 20th anniversary, last night Gibson's rolled back their prices to 1989. Filet: $14 Crabmeat Avocado: $7 Double baked potato: $1 I am still full... next time I'm making the double baked my meal! A+.

Amazing steakhouse!  I did my research on great restaurants before my trip to Chicago and Gibson's did not disappoint.  It was worth the 45 min wait in a fun piano bar I might add.  The steak was incredible as were the sides and I immediately wanted to give my # to whomever created the Turtle Pie slice that was as big as my head.  Our waiter, Craig was my dream come true.  Quick suggestions, stated them as fact and guided us through the process with no B.S.  Oh and Jesse Jackson was loving the place while we were there so it's good to go!

Oh, hello Gibson's, did the recession hit you in the pee pee? Now, I'm an anal bastard.  But every time something like this happens, I get annoyed as fuck.  It's not about the dollar amount, it's the principle.  And these guys violated my consumer rights. Really? $2.49 cents.  That's what these assholes added to my bill. And no, $72.49 looks nothing like $70.00.  We had a table of 6, where we split our bill evenly and we all rounded up to the same amount.  Not a tremendous tip, but definitely nothing to be ashamed of; the waiter wasn't going hungry on a $400+ tab.   I caught you assholes, I'm never going to your restaurant again and I'm calling the card company tomorrow.  You overcooked our steaks for the second time in a month anyway.  Enjoy your 20th fucking birthday, douchebag.   Clearly, Mr. Depp and I don't enjoy the same level of service.

Amazing service and the steak was absolutely delicious....  The wait time wasn't long.....  Happening bar scene....  WR Cut was cooked perfectly and the twice baked potato melted in your mouth....  Make sure to save room for desert!

Really a 2.5 star meal, but I give it 3 because of the service. Ever had a really, really, really good steak? If so, you know they don't usually come in huge, jumbo, and enormous. Gibson's is a lot like a hoity-toity department store - part of what you're paying for is the right to say you ate half a cow there. Don't think I like their wet aging, either. Prefer dry. Both of us had the petite filet, both of us thought, well, that was OK. But just OK. Ordered mine medium rare, but it came out quite a bit more medium. It also had a little grainy texture - like it had been frozen. Doubt  that - or at least hope not - but there it was. The side dish - spinach and mushrooms was disappointing. The little uniformly sized button mushrooms were clearly straight off the shelf from Jewel, and the dish overall was rather bland. Highlight was the sweet potato with brown sugar. Really very good. Didn't have dessert, so can't comment on that. Place was very noisy - lots of manly men pounding back beer and yukking it up. Lots of good looking women partying in groups of 4 and 5 - maybe looking for the gray-haired old men another reviewer mentioned. Friend and I had to shout at each other to heard above the din. Don't get to Chicago much these days, but will most likely spend the time I'm there in the future looking for a better steak.

I like good steak. My 1st time in Chicago, my buddies told me to hit up Gibson's. Great atmosphere. Gibson's reminds me of the old school Steak Houses you see in gangster movies. Our waiter was great, he knew everything about the steaks, and gave us interesting stories about the area. The best thing about Gibson's was when our waiter brought out the cuts of meat for our table to choose. I ordered the bone in New York Steak with lots of garlic. The meat comes out perfect. It was crisp on the outside, soft and buttery on the inside. I could have used my butter knife to cut it. I definitely would recommend Gibson's for anyone looking for a fantastic steak.

So I'm a tourist - the type to hit all the "famous" places and tell friends upon the return home. Gibson's was on the list, so we went. They do not dissappoint. The place is obviously a tourist spot, but not a trap, per se. The food is delicious and our waiter wasn't kidding when he said the food was "cartoonish". The food portions are gargantuan, and I'm not even referring to the steaks. Just go, you'll see.  The service is superb. Clearly the bartenders and waiters have been in the service industry for years, if not, decades. Also, the piano players in the bar area are worth a mention. Too bad you can't hear their beautiful melodies in the restaurant.  Minus one star because my fish was overcooked (but still tasty) and the broccolli looked like they literally grabbed a broc head from the grocery store, threw it in the steamer and then put it on a plate. I know you're a steakhouse Gib, but no need to ignore other things on the menu.

This review is based strictly on the bartenders and the spirits they pour.  If you're looking for a classic, old school establishment where the piano is playing in the background and the bartenders are knowledgeable about the libations they serve - then this is a solid choice.  It takes a moment or two for the bartenders to ease into conversation, but once it occurs, it becomes very obvious that they enjoy what they do and they know their stuff!

3.5 stars really. The glitterati days of sports legends and film stars dining here are long gone, but you can still ogle their photos lining the entry stairwell. No, these days you are more likely to see curmudgeons adjusting their hearing aids, their pearled wives, and a smattering of tourists experiencing 'big city fine dining'. Its across the street from my job, so after greuling days at work I love to hang out at the bar, eat a burger and throw back some wine. The wine list is pretty encompassing and the bartenders have all worked there for twenty years (literally) so they know their stuff. The room is clubby and dark and crowded, there's often a piano player. My one BIG complaint is the bathroom attendant... I hate paying to pee. I am a grown adult and quite capable of turning on a faucet and drying my hands all by myself.

I have heard about this place for years and when I finally got the chance some fellow engineers and I dropped in. The place was super busy, and they got five of us in a booth with no wait.  The wait staff was attentive, and the wine list was good. But the steaks were great. I had the fillet, and several in our party had the rib-eye, everything was perfect. The potatoes were also good.  All in all, it was everything I had heard it was. Nice to see some reputations are continuously earned.

If ridiculously good steak, wine and people-watching are on your radar, head to Gibson's.  It's a Chicago institution and certainly one that has history to it. The steak really is that good ... the servers really are that enjoyable ... and the twice baked potato really is that good. Overall, I had a great time here. I'd highly recommend it for out of town entertaining - my parents loved it. Or, just to go, sit and watch the madness around you.

I give it 4.5 stars! We were starving after getting in late, so walked the 8 blocks from the hotel down to Gibson's for some highly anticipated meat. I got the petite filet mignon (I have a small stomach) with a side of creamed spinach, and bf got a porterhouse with side of mashed potatoes. The house salad was kind of whatevers, but its not like you go to a steak joint for salad right? My steak was good, the perfect size and perfectly cooked. The porterhouse was tasty too, I really liked the salt seasoning on top. Mashed potatoes and spinach were excellent sides, but holy cow, wayyyy too much food. Definite red meat overload. Oh, and I got a raspberry martini which was mmmmmmmmm PERFECT girly drink!! Sugar-rimmed glass and all.  It was about 10pm on a Sunday night when we came for dinner, and it was still really crowded, so I think that's a testament to how popular and well-liked this restaurant is.

you know what im gonna go a little bit different here....im not going to review the steak..if i did..id give this place a 4 what i will review is the planked white fish..and the fillet eggs benedict....i use to work across the street from this place..if it was early enough in the afternoon..id rock out the fillet eggs benedict for a solid $9...are you kidding me..im getting fillet medallions (prime) by the way for $9...i beat the system regularly in here.. the planked white fish...so you dont eat meat..or you dont feel like getting full from dinner...the planked white fish is unreal...it comes planked on a huge log..and makes everyone jealous..it comes with a whole fried tomato and enough whipped potatoes for the table...the white fish comes with a sauce of some sort that is homemade..im tellin you..its a knockout the steak..its gibsons..its a decent steak..i prefer chop house or ruths chris though..sorry gibsons.. the atmosphere is unreal..everyone is always laughing and having a good time.. the piano bar...good time....oooo wait..i completely forgot..the dessert...man o man..the dessert is big enough to share for 4 to 6 people..its a whole cake..carrot, chocolate, red velvet and some other options..even if you go here after dinner somewhere else..grab a slice of cake and some drinks and then go across to the street to jillys piano bar and make a night of it
Nothing special.  Lots of old people and mediocre steak and apps.

Oh Gibsons, what can I say.....Fabulous!    I went on a Sunday evening and the place was PACKED.   The bar area is a good size so waiting for a table is a treat.  I was concerned about the meal as I read some mixed reviews on this site, but I truly must say it was the BEST steakhouse and one of the top restaurants I have had the pleasure of dining at.    I normally would order the filet, but the waitress raved about the bone in Ribeye so I through caution to health and gave in.  What a great move!!   It was spectacular.   Although large enough to feed a small family, the beef was seasoned to perfection and cooked just the way I ordered.  The twice baked potato was amazing, and even the side of spinach was perfect.  I also started with the Wedge Salad and that too was a hit.  The sommelier recommended an excellent merlot to go with dinner and all in all the evening was a hit.   Now, the best part.....dessert.   All 3 of us shared the pecan pie wih vanilla bean ice cream which was out of this world.   All in all, I highly recommend Gibsons, but make sure you bring your wallet as the prices and portions are of good size!
Best Martini in the city, and its enormous! Oysters are always fresh and perfect, and the steaks are top-notch. Classy, old-school vibe. Come for dinner, have a drink at the bar afterwards.

I love red meat. Gibsons is the kind of place that loves people who love red meat.   Their service was fantastic.  Our waiter made a point of telling all of us to take our time - that we had all night.  This was particularly nice since I was there for a business dinner.  Mo (I mention him by name because he was just that good) took care of us all night.  He was Johnny on the spot when we needed him, but never intruded on our long, long conversation. The good: The house salad with crumbled blu cheese and balsamic was fantastic.  Really set the palate.  Mo was well versed in the wine list and recommended a great bottle for the table. The Double baked potato.  I need to figure out their recipe because SHAPOW!  Add in some mushrooms and creamed spinach and you have a MEAL my friends. The ehhhh: I had the bone in sirloin Medium Rare.  From Mo's description this was going to trend toward rare.  Instead it trended toward a full medium.  In a normal situation, I wouldn't bat an eye at this because a nice cut of aged beef is pretty awesome when cooked in a 1800 degree oven. However, if I'm dropping the kind of coin that Gibson's is commanding for a steak, it better be right!  Thus, 4*'s and not 5*'s. Oh, make no mistake my friends, I'll be back.  If for no other reason than the other random events of the night:   1) A dude pretending it was Ancient Rome in the bathroom.  It is truly an amazing thing to hear someone barfing at 8PM on a Wednesday. 2) A ZZ Top guy was sighted while we were there.  I didn't see him, but one of my coworkers did.  It was one of the guys with beards, not Frank Beard.

Their steaks are so yummy it makes we wanna slap someone!  Plus, they are BYOB (with a $20 corkage fee).  If you're not a fan of loud noise, I recommend an early dinner (around 4-5 PM), you still get excellent service but are able to hold a conversation.

This review is for the bar. I've been to Gibsons about 10 times, and 9 of those times have been to just the bar.  Which is one of my favorites in Chicago!  The drinks are amazing, and they have the entire dinner menu available there too.  My favorite thing to order (and it's not even on the menu) are the filet mignon sliders!  They are to die for!  Other than that, I highly recommend the crab cake.   The atmosphere is what I'm all about.  It's an older crowd, but everyone is really nice and just there to have a good time.  Occasionally celebs pop in, but I always have an amazing time with my girlfriends hanging out there chatting with the guys.  The servers are super sweet, and the piano players are always getting jazzy.  You never have to listen to Lil' John screaming "Get Low"! It's great for a girls night out, a date, and you can have some awesome drinks, some amazing appetizers.  I love you Gibsons!
The most amazing prime rib dip sandwich ever. Make that the best sandwich I've ever had in my life.

I love this place. Period. The steaks are amazing, the wait staff is spot on, the sides the atmosphere, I really like this place to get a great steak. I have ordered seafood as well and had nothing but a great experience. It's not cheap but worth what you pay.

Food was delicious but had an average experience.  I always walk by but had never entered until last Sunday. Was seated quickly and the waiter was courteous. It was around noon and I hoped they had a brunch menu. But no. The lunch menu among other things included an 'Eggs' section. I had the Bookbinder's Soup (tomato soup with seafood) and the Fillet Medallions Benedict with Hash Browns. It was ok. Tip: The street meters are now enforced seven days a week until 9 PM. Valet said they may change again and enforce 24/7. Bring some extra quarters if parking on the street.

Mucho choices! Cant go wrong here. You can even ask for the Nick's Fish Restaurant menu and order from there. I've never tried the steak here (ironic) but the salad, bread and the HUGE carrot cake are great. Oh and you must try the mashed potatoes.  Hard to get in on the weekends, tables are a little packed, the bar we could do without but otherwise, not too shabby.

I really enjoyed my filet, but it wasn't the best piece of meat I have ever eaten.  And when I'm paying these prices, every steak should taste like it.  The sides were wonderful, and gigantic, as were the desserts.  The meal as a whole was great, and the service was superb.  I probably wouldn't hesitate to go back, especially on someone else's dime. But my main complaint is the atmosphere.  It just felt way too much like everyone was there to see and be seen.  Shit, Casey Urlacher walked in, and you would have thought it was Michael fucking Jordan the way the hostess and the waiters fawned over him. Whatever.  Take me to David Burke's.

My boyfriend and i wen there for our one year and it was ok. The food was decent, just decent. I was actually kind of dissapointed because I was expecting it to be great. The managers and busboys were great but our waiter sucked. He forgot our drinks twice so we had 2 ask our busboy for them. The food is pricey but it really is not all that great. Ive had better steak at other steakhouses. I will say that the portions were huge, though so you won't go hungry. I don't know if i would be back but i am glad for the experience.
