I didn't want to, but I kind of loved this place. The atmosphere is a tad hokey,  and the whole "dessert that could feed a crowd" thing is a tad tacky, but I was really happy I ate at Gibson's. Plus I saw two NBA players there, for an added bonus. I split a cowboy ribeye here with my man, as well as creamed spinach and twice baked potato. It was all perfectly prepared steakhouse food.  Our waiter was hilarious, I suspect he's an institution at the place. When we ordered off the reserve wine list (ask for it if you care to have a good bottle) he gave us a free dessert. Pretty nice gesture if you ask me.
my boyfriend and i had our first "official" date at gibsons. but that's not the only reason i love it. the food, atmosphere, drinks, service -- outstanding.  p.s. the pecan pie is mandatory.

Talk about atmosphere! I went to Gibson's my first night in Chicago for the Classic Steakhouse Experience and was not disappointed. Gibson's only serves USDA Prime cuts and they were succulent and juicy all the way. Our server was a twenty-year veteran of the industry and treated us like gold. Had an incredible meal with great  California Cabernet and basked in the loud, bustling atmosphere that Gibson's is famous for.

Very over-rated.  I ordered a medium rare rib-eye steak that was first well done than rare.  They coudn't get it right after two tries.... This place sucked......Too expensive for over-cooked and under-cooked food.

Great selection of quality steaks, service that borders on performance (in a good way), and mouth-watering deserts. While Gibson's hovers between a 3 and 4 star, I'm giving them 4, as I have never had a bad experience with the food; it's always been good. But sometimes, there's a little too much canned Chicago that makes me think this is really a 3-star place.

I was on the bubble between 4 stars and 5.  Would've preferred to have given them 4 1/2! I've eaten at the Chicago & Rosemont locations many many times each.  Both are very good and very consistent making Gibson's my 2nd favorite steakhouse in the country. Great food & even better service. -  The T-Bone, NY Sirloin, and Pork Chop are all excellent.  Always prepared exactly as ordered.  Their meat is well-seasoned, and always served with a nice char.  Oh, and the sauteed filet medallions w/peppers are pretty darn good as well.  Their meat is just not as flavorful as Chops in Atlanta, nor is the ambiance quite as nice, hence 4 stars vs 5. -  The sides are also tasty.  I usually go for the creamed spinach and asparagus. -  No matter when I've been there, the piano bar has always been fun and packed before dinner. -  And their Gibson Martini's (have to order a Gibson while at Gibson's, right? :D) are always shaken just right! What I like about this place is the consistency of their kitchens and the old school approach of the waiters who always take care of you.

Haven't eaten there, but sure enjoyed the bar. On a late night stop, a group of nine of us slipped easily into the bar next to the piano player.  It was comfortably loud, with crowd noise and piano music, but we could still hear each other.  Excellent service, fair prices.  Good people watching.  And a great décor.

3.5 stars. There is no doubt that Gibson's had an amazing bone-in rib eye steak and quite possibly the best dessert I've had: Macadamia Turtle Pie. If you go to Gibson's don't waste your money or appetite on the sides. The garlic mashed potatoes were chunky and the garlic tasted raw. The sauteed spinach was boring. The service was OK. The hostesses were casual and the waitress was knowledgeable yet curt.

the twice baked potato is AMAZING! oh... and the ribeye was great too... really good.  the thing i love about this place is the old school steakhouse feel and how everything is on steroids... everything is HUGE... from the potatoes, lobster tail, cake (yes... i actually enjoyed the cake)... me likes.  2 HUGE thumbs up for gibsons.

This place has the BEST hamburger I've ever had!!!!!! We went here for my sisters birthday and I didn't want to break the bank, which is why I order the burger. The waitstaff is fantastic and personable. Although the appetizers are a bit pricey they can be shared among 3 to 4 people. The desert is large and delicious. I fantasize about this burger, and its about the same price as one you would find at TGIF. What a deal! They also have a lunch menu which is a little bit cheaper then the dinner one.

Love this place!  Second time here.  Old school steakhouse with a great bar which features  a pianist playing on a grand piano that takes requests.  With a tip of course!  I recomend  Frank  Sinatra..  My fiance swears that they have the best Grey Goose dirty martini, and for a reasonable $13 and generous pour, I believe here!!  Steaks are fantastic, sides o.k., baked potato huge.  Waiter was an older gentlemen that was on top of his game and our water was never empty thanks to very attentive busser.   Lamb chops overcooked but fixed with a smile.  Finally, it just seems like you could look over your shoulder and see Old Blues Eyes sitting next to you enjoying a cig and martini!!

I liked everything here. From the Hostess to the Owner, to the Server and runners, and bussers, and giant porter house of delicious death, and the crazy ass huge volcano of an ice cream cake, I liked it all. i will stop back in next time I am back in Chicago. First time I had tried the Meritage from DuckHorn, and like their other wines, it was magnificent, went very well with the giant steak of death I consumed.

There are more Chicago steak houses than you can count on your fingers (and possibly toes) so it's important to find the ones that are truly worth your while.  If you're looking for great steaks, excellent service, and live atmosphere, this should be one of your top choices to visit.  The steaks have a phenomenal char, and the tenderness of the steak really shines when you take each bite.  Medium to medium-rare is the way to go IMHO to truly enjoy the high quality of the meat and the contrast between the flavorful char and the tender meat. Recommendations: W.R. Cut - Excellent Rib Eye, but lots of marbling... so make sure you know what you're getting into before ordering it. Filet Mignon - Lean, and surprisingly flavorful for this particular cut.   Mashed Potatoes - As with any good steak house, enough to share with the table... the wine based gravy to go with was alright, but the potatoes themselves are dense and extremely well flavored.  Delicious naked. Avocado Crabmeat (appetizer) - Sounds simple, but with how fresh the avocado and crabmeat were and the dressing that topped it, this appetizer was an excellent opening for all of us.  Unfortunately, the size isn't really a "shareable" appetizer... perhaps more meant for two instead of four. Recommendation for fun: Meaning of Life Cake - Be warned, all their cakes (while slightly pricey) are really 1/4 to 1/5 of a whole cake... and about 7-8 layers tall.  These are meant to feed a village!  This particular chocolate layer cake has layers of bananas, chocolate shavings, and a cherry liquor sauce and then covered with tasty whipped cream with toasted fresh almonds.  Served with vanilla ice cream.  While I've definitely had better cakes, this one is ordered more for the entertainment value of my guests (and to the entertainment value of the tables around us).   Be warned... reservations don't mean you'll have a seat at the same time... We arrived at 7:25, had reservations at 7:30, and were not seated until 7:50... and even then, we were seated about 7 feet behind the hostess area and felt the cold winter breeze at our table regularly. Definitely a go to place in Chicago if you're a steak lover!

Wow. Great steaks here. And mashed potatoes and spinach.  Even if you take half of your steak to go and reheat it in the microwave it tastes delicious!!!! We had reservations but still had to wait a bit for our table to be ready.

I really enjoy myself when I go to Gibson's. The atmosphere is what you would typically expect when you go to a steakhouse. When I was there the other night we were seated at a table for 2 in a booth with 4 other couples in a row. Very cozy.  The food is fantastic. We started with the tomato goat cheese app, which was ok. It is basically a big hunk of tomato and hunk of goat cheese stacked. It was ok. The salads were great. And the steak was fantastic. I ordered mine medium rare and it was served to perfection.  We indulged in a little dessert of an ice cream sundae and after dinner cocktails. The servers were great and we never felt rushed! I can't wait to go back soon!

Definitely the best steak I've ever had.  That being said, I only gave four stars because I'm not one of those people who can just eat a plate of meat for dinner and consider it the best meal of my life. I really liked Gibson's and for what it is, it's great. We took my boyfriend's family here for our Christmas dinner a few weeks before the actual holiday. The service was excellent and we were seated right away with no wait.  My only real complaint about the place is that the tables are really close together and the place gets LOUD. We had trouble hearing eachother and were bumped a few times by adjacent tables. Still, no big deal.  The service was excellent. I was prepared to be prodded and pushed out since it seemed like a touristy type place that is good, but tries to turn tables quickly. Fortunately, our server let us take as much time as we liked and even suggested letting us sit for awhile with our cocktails (GREAT and big martinis! YUM!). He explained the menu and the cuts of meat really well.  I'm glad they come out with the cuts of meat because I was thinking of getting the regular filet until I saw it. It's huge! I got the small filet and that was more than enough meat for me. We also split the sauteed spinach with mushrooms and garlic among us all. It was great. Just a reminder though it seems to be mentioned in every review, the desserts are HUGE! One "piece" of carrot cake is actually 6 big slices. All five of us split one piece and couldn't even finish it.  I like a good steak and I loved the char crust they have here, but I don't know if I'd go back unless I was with a true steakhouse lover. The ambiance isn't anything too special, but the food is delicious, just a little too simple for my taste and for the price.

This is my husbands favorite steakhouse in the city. The food is good. I think the portions are a bit crazy but that is a typical steakhouse for ya!  My biggest issue with this place is the service. I took my husband there for his birthday (since it's his favorite place). I made a reservation about 1 month in advance. We walk in and got seated right away (that was the good part) after that we were completely rushed through the entire experience. We had wine, appetizers, entrees, side dishes and we did the whole date in less than an hour! I felt like I was at a breakfast restaurant. It made me so mad! Our big date night was over in 50 minutes. Some night.  I am not uncomfortable sitting closely to other guests - I've lived in Chicago for over 10 years I'm used to it. This was different - we were a table of 2 sandwiched between 2 tables of 4 and it was so loud. We were also seated right by the kitchen door so the traffic of servers and bus boys was constant.  Good food - terrible experience

Went there for our anniversary dinner. As everyone has said before it's pretty loud, not really a romantic setting if that's what you're going for. We both got the regular size filet, both were cooked perfectly. I was impressed that i asked for blue cheese and he asked for horseradish crusting and even though they weren't on the menu the waiter didn't think twice and said sure. Wine was delicious, a bit over priced compared to their competitors. Twice baked potato was delicious, and 1.5 pounds! I'm not a baked potato person but the inside is almost like mashed potatoes. Dessert was also enormous but nothing to write home about. We got the strawberry shortcake, I wouldn't order it again... the shortcake was kind of hard. Overall, it seems like a great place for a boys night out. You can feel the testosterone in the air!

Excellent service, our waiter Elvis took one look at my wife and told her exactly what she wanted to order(he might be psycic). He was funny and very attentive. The food is phenomenal wil definitely go back on my next trip tho Chicago. It is pricey but you do leave with the satisfaction of having eaten one of the best Restaurants in Chicago. Make reservations as this place gets really busy.

As I am writing this review, The Morning After, I am still stuffed after having eaten at Gibson's at 6:45PM (it's currently 9:45 AM.) I gorged myself with a bottle of reasonably priced (for a steakhouse) Meritage, the 13oz bone-in sirloin, 1/2 double baked potato, and pecan pie. If I had a dog-he would have been ecstatic with the leftovers.  We opted for the pecan pie because, while still wanting something sweet, we didnt want an entire cake. Our logic-order the less expensive dessert.  Also, try a sprinkle of the Gibson's Seasoning Salt they place on the table. Im usually not a fan of enhancing my steaks, but it was there and I tried it. Not too bad and it gives the steak a smidge of extra flavoring.

I never knew you could get a 14oz filet mignon until we visited this place.  While it's hardly "dainty" it was an excellent cut of meat.  As someone who likes pepper, I had mine covered in peppercorn served w/a peppercorn sauce.  The food certainly didn't need this but hey, I like a little spice. The bisque soup is ridiculous, you have to try it.  And you have to try to save room for dessert.  I can't comment on whether or not any of them are any good because nobody told us the portion size was enough to feed the brady bunch.  However, they looked tremendous.  You can probably also share a dessert between 2-4 people as the slices of pie/cake are massive. Oh, and not to be forgotten, the service was very attentive and our waiter, despite being completely slammed, had plenty of time to chat up our table. we'll be back for sure.

It's Gibson's... and it's a Chicago institution. The bone-in rib eye is phenomenal, there's really no fluff when you go here. No chefs trying new things, just a tried and true steakhouse that isn't afraid of it's roots. I wish more restaurants embraced traditions as well as Gibson's. Being from California, sure there are a lot of great restaurants out here, but many of them struggle to try to be something more than they are. I love eating in Chicago, because that food city doesn't have that problem. The size of the portions are very Midwest. It's absolutely the best steakhouse I've been to and Gibson's calls me back to the Windy City at least once a year.

Gibson's is the Abe and Louie's of Boston.  Gibson's is the best it gets for Chicago Steak Houses. The prices are high but that is just to keep the riff raff out. This is where EVERYONE goes when they are in Chicago. The food is excellent and so is the atmosphere.  The atmoshere is really top notch.  The people that are there are either famous or rich or divorced. I love coming here and atmosphere means the world to me. If I am going out and paying for a nice meal, then I want it to feel like this place.  Plus, you are right on Rush and there is tons to do afterward.  Always a good choice if in Chicago, The Chop house is the only thing that comes close to Gibsons, which is cheaper but you suffer on the atmosphere.   Gibsons will never let you down, I have been there ALOT, and sometimes just for drinks because I like the place so much ( Friday, Saturday, the pretty people come out)

I go here for dessert. Dessert = a piece of cake. Piece of cake = 3 solid pounds, 9 layers. The first time the waiter brought it out I fell of my chair laughing because I couldn't believe the sheer size of it. Like when a big fat clown comes out of a tiny car or something. A piece literally a third of the entire cake! The last time I was here I saw a lady that had so much plastic surgery she looked like Madame. You know, the dirty old lady puppet that appeared on Solid Gold with Wayland Flowers in the early '80s.

FINALLY!!!!!! I've been hunting all over the place where I could get a $150 steak dinner.  My search has now come to an end.  Phhewwww! Just kidding.  I didn't have steak.  But if I did it would be dripping with sarcasm too.  I had a $14 piece of cake/pie thing which I had to dig through the couch cushions for hours to fund.  Just kidding.  I was treated.  To be fair the death-by-chocolate style dessert was superb and kept me high as a kite for several days.  And the waiter was probably the coolest in the city.   Thusly in conclusion, come for dessert, and stay for the people/surgery/kept housewife/silicone watching.
Meat. Unadulterated. Aged. Cooked to perfection. Took my parents out to this place while we're in the Windy City at the same time. They were happy. I was happy. Enough said.

I like Gibson's for its namesake. True they're famous for their quality meat cuts, but what a neglectful service! It started at the bar when my beau ordered his martini dirty and the bartender mixed it dry. When the bartender was reminded that is supposed to be dirty he just added olive juice and stirred his glass in front of us. He did NOT even bother to release the glass of previous crap.  When we were finally seated at our table, oysters we ordered never appeared. We had to sit and munch on bread for some decent half hour before our entree was served. When we enquired of whereabouts of our oysters, the server had to reverse our courses. That is, the entrees were taken back to the hidden jungle of their kitchen. So, we finally got hold of oysters. aaa ok. Thought the evening trouble would end there. Not really, the grand finale of Gibson's service fiasco came into conclusion when our previously served steak came out of the kitchen reheated and therefore all dried up.  Uum dessert? No, thank you! PS: It is ironic that my beau met their operations director during his business trip as they arrived to the same meeting. Supposedly we will get comp meal. Lobster tail! Not going there for less :)

Gibsons is the most over rated, over hyped steakhouse in Chicago.  Just because celebrities go there doesn't mean it's any good!  I've never had a meal there that I would consider anything higher than just ok.  Service can be good but at times also very slow.  The atmosphere in the bar is about as cheesy as you can get!  If you want fantastic service and a great steak go to Sullivans!  The staff is wonderful and the food is second to none in Chicago.

I don't get the hype.  Food was average to good.  But WAY overpriced.  So you pay for the neighborhood and ambience I imagine.  Everything they serve here is gigantic, and most goes to waste as the average person cannot eat that much.  Maybe that too is why they charge such astronomical prices. I must say the service was very good though, they all seemed very happy to have our business.  And I enjoyed the dessert (ice cream sundae) more than my meal (whitefish). If you're a celebrity and/or enjoy the "see and be seen" crowd and paying too much for a rather ordinary dinner, this is the place for you. By the way I was treated to this meal by a foolish Cubs fan who bet this Sox fan that the Cubs would make it to the World Series in '08, and we all know how that turned out!  Cubs fans are so silly sometimes!

Just got back from lunch with friends.  I've lived in Chicago all my life and had never made it to Gibson's before.  What a great place!  Every single person who works here was incredibly friendly/nice and the food was great.  Will definitely be a regular from here on out... wish I'd gone before today!

I love me some steak! I am fortunate enough to say that I have dined at some fantastic steak houses but this one seemed average.  The options were the Chop House, Smith's, Mortons, and Gibsons. Looks like I will have fly back and try the Chop House (I had great service at Mortons in New Orleans & MIA, my mouth waters for a Smith's filet with gorganzola.) Everyone was drooling over this place so we tried it. It wasn't bad food or service but nothing to stand out. Honestly, I forgot the name and it has been driving me crazy. Thanks yelp.lol

This was my first time at Gibsons, and I would gladly go back again. My boyfriend and I had planned to go for my birthday dinner, but I waited too long to make reservations and couldn't get a decent time on a Saturday night. We ended up doing a very early dinner around 4PM. We were greeted by every staff member we came across while being led to our table (same on the way out!). Our drink orders were taken right away and our server explained he would be back in a few minutes to show us all the cuts of meat and explain it all to us. We both had salads - my boyfriend had the house, I had the caesar - neither of us were too impressed. There was something a bit "off" about my dressing. We both ordered the filet, and asked for them not to char the steaks on the outside like they usually do. My boyfriend got medium rare, I ordered medium. We opted to split the baked potato. When the steaks arrived, they were both almost well done - we cut them right down the middle and saw NO red on the inside. When our server came back to check on our steaks, he noticed how overcooked they were and was overcome with genuine embarrassment. I told him I would keep my steak, but he insisted on taking both of ours back and getting us new ones. Minutes later, the new steaks appeared, and were absolute perfection. He also brought us fresh potatoes along with our new steaks. Our server said that the staff in the kitchen was more concerned with re-stocking the kitchen rather than cooking the steaks, and he offered us his sincere apologies. He said to be sure to let him know if anything at all isn't to our liking. We were not going to order dessert, since we had seen how huge they were - we were planning on doing some shopping afterwards and didn't want to carry a giant chocolate cake around! But our server surprised us with a HUGE piece of chocolate cake, compliments of the kitchen. It was unlike anything I've ever had - it's two days later, and we're STILL eating leftover cake!  I left with a great impression of this restaurant. I'm not one to send back food, and I was pleased with our servers reaction to everything. It was a very pleasant experience and I can't wait to go back :)

Man.....i miss this place sooo much. Where can I start?  I have lived in the Gold Coast for over 3 years and this place never gets old. The atmosphere is great whether you're with a friend, a date, a group of people, or just by yourself looking to grab a drink at the bar. There's a piano there and a pianist, but I never really notice them playing because there are so many people around that it's just so fun to watch. When it's nice out, i love to grab a lunch outside and watch all the people drive by showing off their leased Lamborghini or whatever other flashy car they have that they need to showcase because they lack self-esteem. Now, the martinis....... I love the martinis here because they're in real glasses, not those whimpy martini glasses that you get at other places.....these are huge. The service. The servers really know their stuff and are very attentive to your needs. The Food Like the martinis, the portions are huge. I had the filet mignon with a side of mushrooms once......very good. I've also had some goat cheese with portebella mushrooms, very tasty And the desert that you have to share because it's ginormous. Once my bf and I got the snickers ice cream cake desert....we couldn't finish it so we gave it to the table next to us filled with a bunch of drunk, middle-aged women in town for a game. All and all, it's an experience and when i head back to Chicago for a visit, i am definitely coming back.

If you love steak you need to go to Gibson's. You'll run into tons of tourist but plenty of Chicago natives make it down to this great steakhouse. While Chicago does have tons of steakhouse this place will give you exceptional service, size-able portions, and a fun atmosphere. You will pay for all of this great tasting food but its well worth it. If you have time and room try the desserts but beware they are huge. If you only have two people in your party expect to take some food home.
All you need to know is "French Fried Lobster tail on a Popsicle stick and hot Chinese mustard".  This is a Hall of fame appetizer and I might just start my Fantasy Food team after this post.

Great steakhouse. Here are a few tips to a better Gibson's experience...it's often packed, but check out the host/hostess outside if you want to sit outside. Inside there was a wait for 1 hour for two people--outside we got seated right away. There are heaters outside which made it extra comfortable--great people watching on Rush Street. Medium Rare is like Rare, so while I usually do Medium, I had to send it back to cook some more. Don't ever leave without trying the twice baked potato. Good service

First steak house in Chicago I've been to. The decor was great and all, but the bar had the worst crowd. The bartenders were fine, but the crowd were all rude to them (probably bc most of them were drunk) and they couldn't even hear what we wanted. That was a total let down and didn't even bother getting a drink and just waited for a table.  The server was great, showing and explaining all the cuts and seafood they had available. As we wanted to try a bit of everything, we decided to share our meal. Thought this might get them offended, but instead, they gave us an extra cup of gumbo! The meat of good, but had better elsewhere. But, goers must try the double baked potato. Not sure how they double bake it, but it seemed like they took mashed potato and stuffed it back into the potato shell (?). You might want to share that though bc it's HUGE.

Gibsons is situated on Rush Street, lined with Ferraris and Lamborghinis so I thought to myself as I stepped in, I was going to be stepping out with my pockets empty. To my surprise it is on par with most steak houses.  I ordered the Chicago Cut and a baked potato (which was HUGE), medium rare. I'm a steak lover and have been to quite a few steak houses in my life (mostly for free thanks to my old career as an investment analyst where mutual fund wholesalers try to shmooze you).  To match with the price, the steak was on par as well.  It wasn't mind blowing uber elite ninja food, however it was good.  The steak was juicy albeit it did seem a bit cold and tough by the time I was done (I am a fast eater). The service was great however, classy, fast, welcoming. It should be for a $70 meal. If I go to Chicago again, I'll probably check out other steak houses, it doesn't mean I will won't be coming back though. 3.45 stars because I don't want to round up.

I like steak.  So sue me.  Moreover, I like steak served in old-fashioned restaurants staffed by old-fashioned waiters who aren't afraid to tell you what to do.  Ergo, Gibson's is my kind of place. My porterhouse steak was juicy, tender, and properly cooked.  The blue-cheese seared on top didn't hurt, either.  My dining companions were equally impressed with the bone-in ribeye and Chicago cut.  The garlic mashed potatoes came with actual minced pieces of actual fresh-roasted garlic mixed in, which is a good sign.  The broccoli was sci-fi big, and not overly flavorful.  But it was necessary for us to eat it in order to forestall any attempts on its part to take over the world.  Which is just another way to say, it really was quite big. Dessert seemed like a good idea [frankly, when you're me, it ALWAYS seems like a good idea].  I was all set to have the carrot cake, but the waiter turned me down flat.  "It's 3 pounds," were his exact words.  "Instead, you have the peach pie."  Okay, I will.  But, before we move on, let me ask you: seriously?  3 pounds?  This seems necessary to....who?  In the alternative, let's try this: I'll pay you the same $10, you cut that cake into thirds, bring me one third, take the other two thirds back to your kids, and we'll all be happy.  See?  There IS a solution to this. Anyway, the peach pie was smaller.  Which is to say, it was only a quarter of the pie.  Seriously.  No, really.  When we called him on it, the waiter admitted we were right.  I ate maybe a quarter of it.

One of the first places I ever ate at in this city. My dad and I went here and were impressed we didn't have to wait long, considering the place was pretty full for lunch. I got a tasty chicken sandwich with an insanely delicious spicy mayo that I swear had to have crack in it because I still get a craving for it to this day. My dad went for steak and loved it. Our server was nice and explained to us some great spots to go in the city. The ambiance was great and for being in the Gold Coast, it wasn't that expensive. I keep on coming back here when I show my friends around the city.

Gibson's throws down old school. This is your fathers or grandfathers or even great grandfathers' place. This is not new or hip or fresh. Gibson's is gin martinis, red wine and huge platters of red meat. If you want something fancier go to Keefer's, if you want something more approachable and less expensive, get thee to Wildfire. Gibson's introduced me to the bone-in filet. The flavor difference is remarkable which is important in a filet mignon because it is so lean. For appetizers I usually go old school too and get the shrimp cocktail, but I have to say the crab-stuffed avocado is quite good and I've also sampled the chopped garbage salad which was wonderful. I'm not big on desserts in restaurants. I think that more often than not they are overpriced and not very good. A friend who knows that I make a great carrot cake ordered it and had me try it. I thought mine was still better, but it was definitely one of the best cakes I've ever had in a restaurant.

For me Gibsons in Chicago was the start of my journey to eat at every upscale steak house as possible so I will never forget it. This review is about 15 years old so everything may be different, but I felt the need to pay homage to the place. In fact, a very good friend who is on the same steak journey I am on frequented the place twice very recently and commented that he did not think it was anything special. I will not change my positive remarks on the first bone in Ribeye I have ever had until I myself have a chance to eat there once more. For posterity of course.

Back in April when we had a warm spell (for a second) I met some coworkers at Gibson's for dinner.  Again, if you have read my other reviews you will know that I am not a big steakhouse person and would prefer to be dining at one of Chicago's contemporary cuisine restaurants for the money that we end up spending at the darn steakhouses. Anyway off my soap box. . . So the 3 of us tried to get a table with no reservation at around 7:30 on a weeknight.  We were told that seating inside was not available until 9:00, but we were offered a spot on at an outside table right away.  We took it.  It was still a bit too cold to be sitting outside and quite windy.  But this meal was not my idea- otherwise we would have had reservations in advance. Service was not particularly memorable.  Not good or bad, just not anything special.  I like when servers have some sort of personality.  I had a house salad and a petite filet mignon.  It was cooked to my specifications.  WE split the asparagus.  My companions had the chicken and the rib eye and seemed very happy.  We did not have dessert.  It was kind of a short and not every memorable meal for being such a well known steakhouse in Chicago.

I went there for the first time last night and it was great! I ordered some Pinot Grigio and the avacado and crab. So yummy!!!! I truly wanted wanted to order the lobster, but I didn't want to spend $100 on it.

In the meat and potatoes midwest Gibson's is the ultimate steakhouse, great steaks, great service, and the bar is always packed from open till close.  The ribeye is great as are the sides, the decor is nothing fancy sort of a boys club feel, and the place is always packed.

LIKE PIZZA AND SEX... Even when it's bad, it's still pretty good.  Not that my experience was bad, I just left feeling that it wasn't great.  I also left 5 pounds heavier and a few bills lighter, but I digress...  Having eating at some fantastic steak houses across the US (Peter Luger, Chop House, the Dal Rae, etc.), Gibsons certainly had some big shoes to fill.   Despite getting cholesterol numbers back from my physical that almost require scientific notation (is it my daily bacon milkshake?), I opted for the ribeye as a nice steak dinner is a special occasion type of meal for me.  And it was...good.  Just good.  Not great, not transcendent, not life-changing.  My eyes did not roll back, there was no silent pause after the first bite, the heavens above yielded no golden rays, and the angels sang no hallelujahs...for while this was a good steak...it just wasn't great.   And in this town, for those prices, I don't expect good.  I expect great.

They don't make steak in CA like they do in the midwest, and Gibson's is no exception. Ordered shrimp, steak, potatoes, asparagus, and we had some kind of dip appetizer. It was yummmm. The cocktails are good too. The place is a meat market (no pun intended), it seems like most of Chicago is anyway-- so many men! Good food, great service, give it a try.

I've tried Gibsons twice because the first time didn't impress me, but I always give a place a second chance.  Unfortunately the second time was just as bad.  It's pricey, but that doesn't bother me.  I'm willing to pay for high quality, but I just don't get it here.  I had the filet both times and it was about the same thing I could get at Outback.  The service was fine and the decor was as well, but when I go to a steakhouse it's because I want a kick ass steak and quite honestly Gibsons doesn't deliver that.

The secondary debate between New York & Chicago (the first being Thin Crust vs. Deep Dish)...  Who has the better steak? From all the reviews on the various online websites and word of mouth from Chicagoans, Gibson's Steakhouse seemed to be the preferred choice. Thus, my venture to Gibson's Steakhouse was conducted and can conclude my experience with a single term... UTTER DISAPPOINTMENT!!! Pros:  - Unpretentious dining environment! - Eloquent décor through each dining area! - Helpful and attentive wait staff - Portion sizes, come hungry! - The dessert!  The Chocolate Turtle Pie was Gluttonous Heaven! Cons: - The taste!  This should hardly be considered a steak! - Price! $48.50 for a steak I could've done @ home for a  of the price! The Décor:  The mahogany inspired wooden panel and furniture plays to the subtle and relaxed atmosphere of the restaurant.  This is greatly aided by the off white table clothes used in their dining area to bring out the enchanting lighting of the restaurant.  Strategically placed celebrity autographed pictures (which were by no means few and far between), aided in the bars social scene.  Such separation was well executed by the restaurants heads to disseminate a relaxed bar environment to that of a subtle and quaint restaurant atmosphere. The Food:  "I Came Here For the Porterhouse!"  Those words echoed wonders as I informed our server of my intentions.  There was no swaying of my decision to taste and consume a cut from the B. Taurus Species of the Bovidae Family in the Animalia Kingdom; the Porterhouse was THE choice, the ONLY choice! Server:  How would you like your steak prepared? Chun: Medium Rare is great; I don't want it overcooked... Server: Would you like the steak bloody? Chun: Most preferred, Thank You! With those words, my steak was off for preparation. The 28oz Porterhouse:  Upon presentation of the illustrious wonder, the 28 oz Porterhouse did not boast the merit or presence for which it's been graced!  The first visually detected contrast was that the preparation of the steak was done on a grill and not that of a broiler, this preparation process alone skewed any lingering respect I might've had for this restaurant!  The taste itself was in essence a contrast, the outside edges of the steak contained the consistency of that a well done texture, with the meatiest portion of the inners having that of a raw texture.  This is evident with a steak is grilled and not broiled.  Another drastic discovery of the steak was detected through consumption.  The first bite of this "consumable" (if they can call it that) was bland and rough in nature (signs of overcooking).  What was even more frightening was that the absence of fat in this presentation had me ponder on two fronts... 1) Was this a true USDA Prime Steak? 2) Was this Steak even aged before they decided to throw it on the Grill? Lastly, due to the lack of abundant marbling found in a well selected piece of Porterhouse, the steak lacked the proper taste and texture to that of one that was well executed.  This produced a profound lack of taste, thus requiring me to use their house BBQ sauce.  Sadly, that didn't make much difference. There was one saving grace of this experience... Throughout lunch, I saw the same dessert being carted off to various tables near our seating area.  We politely asked our server for what was later titled "The Chocolate Turtle Pie". The Chocolate Turtle Pie:  This dessert was a fully representation of the Chicago mentality of "Bigger is Better" with their food applications.  The presentation of the dessert contained a base later of pie crust made from graham crackers, brown sugar, and cinnamon.  The crust was then topped with  gallon of Haagen Daaz Vanilla Ice Cream (I kid you not about the amount of Ice Cream).  The dessert was finished off with strategically placed Macadamia Nuts throughout the side of the mountainous dessert and was topped with a heavy drizzle of milk chocolate.  If there was a more elaborate dessert made available, I would like to see it.  The taste did not disappoint.  All of the ingredients mended together to produce a comforting yet humbled appreciation of such a monstrosity.  Despite the size itself, the buttery smoothness of the ice cream greatly aided the sugary crust thus resembling that of a Molasses Ice Cream Cookie Sandwich.  The addition of the Macadamia Nuts greatly aided in the execution by giving the dessert a crunchy and nutty flavored element.  Needless to say, this is a must have while visiting Gibson's! Despite Chicago's most preferred efforts, the lack luster disappointment that is Gibson's Steak did not boast well for my farewell meal.  If Gibson's is representative of the Steak that's harnessed by Chicago, I'd like to say that New York's version wins hands down.

I loved my prime rib!! Sure it's $42 but it's  for a piece of juicy well flavored piece of meat that's the size of your face. it was so big that I had to give VERY generous portions to five other girls and i still only ate half of what was left.  ...and for all of who think i have a girly appetite,  i don't (i'll eat 18 oz w/ no prob). The bachelorette ate the WHOLE prime rib all by herself  (it's that good) The sides we had were creamed spinach (okay), mashed potatoes (pretty good) and spinach w/ mushroom (really good). And to boot, our waiter gave us a recommendation of a wine of great value that wasn't in the $80 range. I appreciate that.

I just don't get it.  Heard all the hype & went to Gibson's expecting the best steak of my life.  Walked away feeling cheated.  Not only was my otherwise good quality filet tasteless & undercooked, but the sides were just a slightly elevated version of your average school cafeteria...bland, boring, barely edible.  Parting words?  Gibsons: Sizzler goes glam.

I can't believe people give this place 5 stars. Seriously the sides were ok, most bland "garlic" mashed potatoes I've ever had. Meat was good, but its all about the show here. I would rather go someplace where its about the food and not the show of the restaurant. Waiter was awesome, service rocked, great wine list, we had a cool table tucked in the indoor patio corner. If only the food was better, I'd rock 4 or 5 stars. Sorry gibson's, we really were cheering for you.

This was recommended to me as a nice restaurant in a great location. In fact, the location used to be (if I have my story straight) Mr. Kelly's where Sinatra used to hang out a lot. Anyway, Gibson's was great. The food was great, the service was even better. I had an early lunch so they weren't crowded at all and I did not have to wait. The waitress recommended the hamburger to me so I went with it. It was excellent. I'd definitely add Gibson's to my list of stops for future Chicago visits.

The Tyrannosaurus Rex tour of Chicago continued with Gibson's tonight. Yesterday was a rib-eye so today called for filet mignon. I see this establishment is hated as well for its crowds, noise, and hype, more so than the Weber Grill it seems. I must be easy to please, because I just loved my meat today. It too was also charred well on the outside, yet pink on the inside as medium rare should be. It was tender as all get out, and juicy to the max. The Bearnaise sauce on the side was full of buttery goodness. I'm not sure how many years tonight took off my life. The garlic spinach with mushrooms was one nice side dish. I kept eating it until my teeth bristled with that irony texture. Portions were big enough for 5 of us to share. The asparagus with hollandaise sauce was somewhat disappointing. It didn't have much pizazz. The salad that comes with the steak was nothing special, just iceberg lettuce with a ton of dressing. I like the drowning of dressing but I know it's bad for me. The place was crowded as all get out, but noise was fine since we were seated in the glass enclosed outer patio room, and was placed in the corner with a great view of the street life. Service was great and attentive. Prices are quite amazing with the grand porterhouse running around $90 and the giant lobster tail at $125 or so. They do have some entrees under $15, so you can eat there on a budget too. So far so good on the carnivorous tour of Chi-town. The tour concludes tomorrow with Fogo de Chao. I expect meat and meat goodness, and will post tomorrow!

I've recently visited Gibson's for the first time and I think it is way overrated.  Maybe I ordered my steak wrong, maybe it was an off night for the place, but my steak didn't live up to all the hype.  Service was good, prices are par with other steak houses, overall and okay place.

I was only here once, cuz let's face it, I'm not made of money.  I had a great time, maybe it was the company, or maybe it was the perfectly cooked, juicy steak and delicious potatoes.  A Chicago classic, well worth checking out.
I think this whole joint is overratted. The meat is good here, but so is at like a 100 other steak houses in the city. The service is good, but so is at like another million restaurant in the city.

Great steak house. The crowd is much different here mostly because of it's location... richer and older. Think all american 50-60 yr olds with cigars and botox... lots of botox.  Service was good and so is the food. It's charred to perfection although I do like a little more char on my steaks. Pretty pricey but then which steak house isn't? If you have room for desert, get it. It's massive and you can offer some to the table next to you if you're feeling generous. A must for steak lovers.

This place consistently lives up to it's reputation (very pricey!). Top-notch steaks and fabulous sides. I really liked the Australian lobster tail and sliders I paired w/ a great bottle (or two!) of wine while dining al fresco on a beautiful afternoon recently...it doesn't get any better than that!

This restaurant is BIG.  That's the best adjective I can use to describe it.  Big drinks, big steaks, big side dishes, BIG desserts (OK, those are more mondo-rific, but you get my gist!) We came here on a Friday night for dinner with some out-of-town friends.  We met in the bar, where a piano player was playing (which was lovely).  And it was packed already (at 6pm!)  Thanks to reservations, we were seated shortly. Our server comes over, takes our drink orders then comes back with a HUGE plate of meat.  He's very knowledgeable, and efficient, clearly a veteran of the steak-house serving. I had beef on the brain (a safe bet when coming here).  So I ordered the small filet (which is plenty of beef for this girl).  Unfortunately, my medium was closer to medium-rare, and dare I say rare.  It was very cool in the middle.  Now, I hate to be THAT girl who sends stuff back, but if we're paying $30 for a teeny piece of beef, it better be cooked appropriately.  So we kindly spoke to one of the bus-persons and asked him to take it back. It was brought back in a timely fashion, and the server checked back with me to ensure it was cooked appropriately.  Honestly, it STILL wasn't medium, but it was hot in the middle, which is all I really cared about.  Not much flavor to the steak, and not nearly as tender as a filet should be.  I was sorely disappointed. However, the service is top-notch (the guy with the pepper mill came out of nowhere!), the ambience is fun (old-school) and the place is phenomenal for people-watching. Definitely not my finest steak, but it was an enjoyable meal with good company.

Went to the legendary Gibsons Steak house in Chicago and was at first a little disappointed.  The bread and salad were mediocre at best, but i was cheered by the icey cold beer the waitress brought  me. But then my steak came.  And it was perfect.  One of the best ribeyes i've ever had.  Incredibly flavorful with a delicious 'crust' but still perfectly medium rare inside.  Steak is usually a tremendous disappoint to me, so i was thrilled that i hadn't wimped out and ordered something lowfat. The fries looked a lot better than they tasted, but they were good enough.  I'd go back in a heartbeat.
We visited Gibson's one Sunday afternoon, after attending a play in Chicago. It was one of the best meals that we have had. It is a classic old steak house. Great service, wonderful food.

How can one not love Gibsons? The best-kept secret is to come on a weekend afternoon for lunch.  The prices are inexpensive (yes...inexpensive was written for a review of Gibsons!) and it is a bit less crowded.  The selection for lunch is just as good as the dinner selection. The patrons of Gibsons never disappoint.  A mix of tourists, neighborhood locals, Viagra triangle gentlemen, and cougars.  The people-watching may or may not be just as fun as eating the food.
Well I make sure I go at least twice if i am there for 5 days. It is hard to find people thats want go back  its alot of red meat. A+

Thanks for the memories, Gibsons.  Where Mr. Drunky Mc Drunks meet Ms. Drunky McDrunks. I haven't been around this area in a while and my trip there last night made me remember why. Last night a woman was so drunk they had to call the paramedics. At 9:00.  A dude WAITING FOR HIS CAR outside was drunkenly muttering unintelligibly. I did think the servers were a little standoffish but I would be too if I had to serve some of the drunken raging a-holes that appear to populate this place. The food is awesome though.  Worth a trip to the second floor: the signed pictures of the many celebrities, some long forgotten, are very entertaining. I found 2 Bob Hopes!
Possibly the best steak I've ever had.  An all-around great meal, impeccable service and great location.  Even better that my father in law paid.
This place is as much Chicago as corrupt politicians.  Just solid steak.

I eat a lot of steak.  A.  LOT.  So with all my visits to steakhouses, you need to do something pretty special to get me to come back again.  Gibson's has the same cuts and quality of meats as most others.  The menu's pretty standard, and the drinks are poured nicely.  So what sets them apart?  I've always had excellent service here.  So I don't know if I'll crave Gibson's in particular, but I'll definitely go back knowing I SHOULD have great service again.

Gibsons is a mixed bag.     Are the steaks good?   yes.    Are they worth the price?  Probably not.    Are the potatoes and sides good? sure.    Again, worth the price?   Probably not.     Salad dressings, as some have said - very potent.     The vinaigrette tastes a bit like plain vinegar and the bleu cheese dressign a bit like pureed bleu cheese.     The service is outstanding but at minimum 20% for 2 people having steak and a side, they are getting $25 - $30 to treat you that well and hey, I will treat you better for that much.      The one thing that I must rave about is the bernaise sauce.     This was a big surprise and usually very hard to get right.    They got it right!
The best thing about Gibson's is the carrot cake. For like $14 you literally get about a  quarter of a 3 tiered carrot cake, which is enough to feed a 2nd grade class (public school, not private.)

This is our second fave steakhouse in Chicago!  We loved going to this place, from the atmosphere to the service, everything was awesome!  When we sat down and had gotten our appetizer of crabmeat avocado, which was AWESOME, the manager came up to us and handed us another appetizer that was a mix of cold items like olives and other stuff and told us our appetizers and dessert were on him tonight!!  We were shocked but gladly accepted!  WTF just happened!?!?  We were so confused but it definitely made an impression on us and we therefore recommend this place to anyone looking for a good steakhouse.  For our entrees we had the filet and the prime rib, which I remember being awesome!  The sides we had were the sauteed spinach with mushrooms and the mashed potatoes which were yummy.  We had gone for my husband's birthday, and the waitress brought us our their strawberry shortcake which was AMAZING...I have not had another one that even came close to this one!!  And I just looked at the menu online to see if it's even on the menu and it is not, and I don't believe it was at that time either...but when we go back I will definitely be asking if they have it!  Overall, if you love good service and excellent food, you cannot go wrong with this one!

I'm stuffed.... couldn't even finish the Chicago Cut. I got it w/ melted blue cheese and it was delicious! (They really do make whatever you ask them to so that was nice!) Some of my friends even ordered seafood off the sister restaurant's menu. And the Porterhouse was well-liked... We had a lot of soups and salads and small appetizers. I highly recommend the tomato and goat cheese. The goat cheese was to die for! Everything else was just okay. For sides, we got 2 plates of fries, a plate of asparagus, a plate of mushrooms and mashed potatoes. None of the sides were spectacular but it's good to have them to compliment all that meat! (I usually don't eat that much meat.) We also got two bottles of red wine, recommended by our server.  For dessert, we made a failed attempt at finishing the German Chocolate cake (aka MOUNTAIN!). It was good but definitely not authentic. It tasted more like Tres Leche.  All in all, I'd go back but I have to check out a few more steakhouses for comparison.

You gotta love Gibson's. Yeah it may be Little expensive, but who cares !the food and drinks are excellent it so worth it. I make the trip to the(Rush st.) location at least twice a month. It's a great place to relax socialize and enjoy life, the piano bar adds a special touch to this gem in the city.

One of the more expensive steakhouses. Huge steaks. Your steak order does not include any sides, but comes with soup or salad. The Chicago Cut is really very good. The service is good. The lamb chops (medium well) was kinda chewy. The baked potato is HUGE (the waiter said, 2 lbs. can you say, hormones?). We ordered one to split 4 ways. The carrot cake is SUPER-HUGE (think: a half-gallon of milk, I'm not kidding!), but not that good. A bit dry, not moist enough, light on the sweet.

Solid, solid four star experience. Great, simple gin martini.  They've got the crushed ice down to a science. The vinaigrette on the house salad was a bit potent. I usually go for a petite filet, but couldn't resist trying the W.R.'s Chicago Cut.  What's not to like about a bone sticking out the side of your steak?  Loved the peppered crust on this steak.  Sadly, though, she was overcooked and seemed a long way from medium-rare.  Still juicy, though.  Had a baked potato on the side, which was delish, skin and all.  Found a nice glass of Sonoma cab to go along with the steak.  I liked that they had plenty of by-the-glass choices. My wife got the pork chop, which was very tender and juicy.  We all love juicy pork, don't we? Our group skipped dessert, too stuffed to continue.  Great, exuberant atmosphere and the service was top notch.

My sister in law and her fiance'  had their wedding rehearsal dinner here last w/e.  Although i've lived in chicago for over 12 years I had not dined at the famed Gibson's, so naturally my expectations were sky high.  All in all it was a pretty good experience. The look and feel of the place was exactly to a T what I expected, which is a good thing: a legendary steakhouse oozing w. history, class and professionalism with the predictable (albeit still cool and interesting) pictures of notable chicagoan's and hollywood/world celebs adorning the walls ...now to the steak. I went w. the bone in Ribeye (WR Cut), an enormous cut of meat that was probably no less than 3" thick.  Came out as the requested Med - Rare with an excellent char on the outer part of the steak.  It was pretty flavorful (not incredibly so) but was a little on the tough side.  I've had  better steak elsewhere in Chicago but it was still good.  It would prob get a 4-star but for the price, which I wouldn't mind paying (and in this case, I didn't;), there is absolutely zero margin for error, in that the steak should be a perfect 10 (ok, 9 maybe even 8/10 is the least acceptable), every single time...i'd rate this one a 7. I'll probably go back at some point but with no shortage of quality steakhouses in Chicago (even those serving only "Prime" cuts like Gibson's), it might be awhile.

My 20 year old brother (at the time) found this joint because he read about it in Maxim.  Our waiter was Moe (and has been for years to follow.)  He came out with a plateful of meat and slapped it around, explaining what each cut was and the lobster tail was gynormous!  If you want anything that isn't on the menu, you'll get a "not a problem!" response - just ask!  I usually get a chopped onion/tomato/blue cheese with viniagrette salad.  Soooo good and sooo not on the menu.  They don't have seared tuna on the menu either, but seem to find it when asked. The bread is from Corner Bakery and the raisin bread is especially made for Gibson's.  Sides are a la carte and can be shared amongst 2 to 4 people.  The potato is as big as a football.  The filets are awesome! For birthday's, all the waiters stand around the table grunting some inaudible chant and then break.  The dessert served is usually a macadamia nut ice cream pie but you can ask for the carrot cake or others listed on their menu.  But, they are HUGE.  By the time you've already eaten a huge dinner, the last thing you need is a huge dessert, so be forewarned if you think you're getting something on a small plate - only order 1, esp. for a big table! There is a huge bar when you walk-in on the right with often times a pianist playing, a coat check and cigar stand on the left, bathrooms are up the front stairs (which are decorated with pictures of many famous people that have walked those halls over the years), and private dining rooms upstairs.  The atmosphere is dark wood, dimmed lights, very romantic or great for a family dinner.  My brother in turn got engaged here. Gibson's also shares a kitchen with Hugo's Frog Bar next door, so if you want the taste of Gibson's without the price, try Hugo's.

It's been several years since I've been here or Chicago for that matter but Gibson's is how I remember it. I am a sucker for timeless joints like this. The atmosphere, the energy, the piano player all rock. We had such a great time here. Although I did not dine this time I did last time and I remember it being quite good, just what you would expect from this kind of joint.

If you like red meat, booze, and a great atmosphere this is the place for you. Right smack in the middle of the Viagra Triangle you might get lost in the beef at this place (pun intended). This place has my favorite steak in town, the WR Chicago cut. This steak is a gorgeous bone in rib eye that tastes like a dream. I normally get it with bleu cheese melted on top. Wow my mouth just watered thinking about it. Well if you can make it out there make sure you make reservations because Gibson's is the place to be and enjoy a Gin Martini on me.

My girlfriend and I ate here the other night because we had a craving for red meat, which we both don't normally eat. This was shockingly my first time going here, having been to many of the other steakhouses in the city. We didn't have a reservation but managed to get in on a Saturday in twenty minutes. We split the small New York sirloin, which the server recommended for us. This was good, but too fatty and hard to chew. I would order a different cut of meat next time. The macadamia turtle pie was amazing! It is worth trying even if you aren't with a large group. I went back for the super bowl and tried their filet mini burgers. These were crazy good and let's just say I fulfilled my red meat fix that weekend!

I prefer dining at Gibson's for lunch rather than dinner.  At night, they pack people in to the point where you're situated closer to the strangers at the next table than the companion you're sitting across.  I ordered the Kobe rib eye, but wondered whether if it was real Kobe.  It surely didn't taste any different nor was it any more tender.  The lunch scene is much more comfortable.  I highly recommend the lobster roll (lunch menu only), which contains big, delicious chunks of meat with a light mayo and enfolded by a wonderful Texas toast.  I could eat that every day.  Day or night, service is excellent.

I went there with my relatives who live in chicago. Unfortunately we had a waiter who was desi, as we are. So he thought we didn't know anything and tried to give us steak with masala and everything, desi style. now i know its out of good heart and everything but that ruined the steak place for me. me and a couple of my cousins were really getting pissed, we just wanted a normal steak, not spiced. if i needed to add spices and masalas to my food i would get a meat that has no taste like chicken. but steak come on man, it taste amazing just with butter. a tender and juicy steak thats all I was asking for. so the meal went on he brought this food out spiced and just wasn't fun or good. hopefully i will get to go again and have the true gibson experience but so far i havent. but i will give the guy credit on service he did a good job, but just tried to hard.

I know this is a Chicago classic, but I think they benefit from their reputable name. The steaks are ok. I have been to most of the steak houses in this city and say Gibson's is right smack dab in the middle of the pack. Nothing special and overpriced. My steak was overcooked...which drives me crazy and basically ruins the meal. They have the guy cut it open in front of you to check  as well. Shouldn't he know that steak wasn't medium rare. I guess I could have sent it back but that isn't really my style.

One word can best describe the steaks at Gibson's, inconsistent. While I have had some very good steaks here, I have to say that I am very unimpressed with how often I have been let down, by the steaks that is. I will say that the sides and desserts, as well as the service and cocktails, are never a let down. Unfortunately, I don't question the quality of the beef as much as the abilities of the kitchen. Shame on you.

Best meal I had in Chicago when you factor in food quality, service, atmosphere and price. Come early and head immediately to the bar to the right of the entrance.  Order a martini with blue-cheese stuffed olives.  Watch as this fishbowl-sized martini glass makes it way to you.  Watch the couples and cougars flirt in the bar and listen to the live piano while you sip your drink.  Take your time.  The bar is gorgeous and dinner can wait. Ready for dinner? Get the steak, please.  It's a steakhouse, remember?  Tons of food, good side dishes and excellent service.  The wine list is interesting, too, because you'll need a big red with your big steak. But the next time I go, I may just stay in the bar all night.  It's a fun spot.

*whack* *splat* *gag* That is the audio to accompany this visual: The waitress brings out the "meat plate." The plate contains about 4 different cuts of raw beef. Sounds pretty cool to be able to see such a thing in a steakhouse, right? Wrong. Not when the waitress picks up the T-Bone by what she calls, "the handle" and starts swinging it around and smacking into the plate about 6 inches from the customer who asked for the seafood menu.  I was stunned, but we still ordered two steaks, and a shrimp plate. The shrimp plate seemed nice and simple, the fillet mignon and the porterhouse were nothing special - I mean, they were huge and tender, but were not particularly flavorful, juicy, or charred very well. The twice baked potato tasted like it had been sitting a while and was not that exciting and the broccoli was downright boring since you could taste the water it had been cooked with. The funniest thing had to be the salad which consisted of iceberg lettuce (which I've heard described as the polyester of greens) and a ton of ranch dressing. Yes, I know, I ordered the ranch dressing, but when a waitress even gives you that as an option with a straight face you know the salad deserves nothing better.  The dining room was crowded, loud, and reminded me of an aging sports bar with dark wood and brass fixtures. And the crowd...oh the crowd...let's just say that now I understand why they call this little section of Chicago "The Viagra Triangle."

Whhaaaattt? How have I not reviewed Gibsons?? Probably because I just don't appreciate a good steak. I know, I know...how dare I live in Chicago and not appreciate a good steak.  I do love Gibson's seafood friendly sister Hugo's...so much so that I always order off of Hugo's menu when eating at Gibson's (they conveniently share a kitchen). This has never been a problem in the past, but tonight when I asked for Hugo's menu my waitress glared at me like I had just run off with her husband. Well, excuse me for not being a meat lover! Much to my waitress's dismay Hugo's made me some delicious grilled shrimp. The rest of the meal was just eh- i'm guessing that the fact we just walked in at 9:30 on a Wednesday night had something to do with it. The salad was actually kind of inedible, the double baked potato (usually so good) wasn't anything special, and the side of broccoli was just broccoli (I expect more from Gibsons).  And....when it came time for dessert they didn't have my favorite banana cake. My, oh my....what has happened to Gibsons? Tonight's experience at Gibsons was 3 stars (if even that), but because they share a kitchen with my beloved Hugo's and it's not really fair for me to judge a steakhouse when I'm not a steak lover I'll be generous with 4 stars. And they may actually earn that 4th star if they put that banana cake back on the dessert menu!
Came here for drinks.  What a great place with the piano bar and good friendly crowd.  The bartender was a bit stodgy, but that just is part of the package in a place like this.

Best steak I've had in the city!!  The service is amazing, the house wine is delicious and the side dishes are to die for (highly recommend the mashed potatoes and sauteed spinach and broccoli - heavenly!!).  Great spot for weekend dinner and close to other places to barhop before or after.  Been here 3 times and can't wait for my next visit!  A bit pricy but worth it.  I've never had enough room to try the desserts - they are huge!

A friend took me here when I went to go visit him in Chicago.  I never knew steaks could be so tender and delicious.  The service was great...I especially like how the guy with glasses comes up to your table with a plate of meat and explains every cut.
No pun intended but, HOLY COW!!   If you want to eat meaty goodness and leave completly satisfied and slightly aroused, go to Gibson's.  Now.

Simply awful. I'd recently moved to Chicago a year ago and kept hearing people refer to this place as Chicago's best steakhouse. So when my parents from out-of-town visited I brought them here. Big mistake. My dad loves steak and was looking forward to a good dinner.  Instead the place was painfully noisy, the meat was either overcooked or undercooked and the vegetables were huge but tasteless. Definitely not worth the huge bill we paid at the end of the meal. Trust me, stick to Morton's. I don't get why people rave about this place.

Some of the best steak anywhere, and definitely my favorite steak experience.  Good people watching in the heart of the Viagra triangle.  If you don't know what I mean, you will once you're there.  For sure get the giant twice-baked potato as a side and DO NOT leave without getting the turtle pie for dessert (one is plenty for any sized group...even up to eight...no joke).

Best cuts I've had in the city.  Classic old world/old money feel, but can be a tad over the top.  It was noisy & hectic but that all quickly faded away with the first bite of a filet that melted in my mouth.  If you LOVE steaks, you will LOVE Gibsons.

Everything done is perfection...the location, ambiance, food, service, music, wine, martinis.  I have enjoyed each trip to Gibsons, be it with family for a quiet dinner, a work gathering for dozens of people or just drinks with friends.  It is suitable for any kind of evening and the staff welcomes each and every patron.  Then there is the food...the filet can not be beat...seriously...you can't even imagine.  It's daunting to select which side to indulge in so you'll just have to keep going back.  Enjoy!

Because I'm new to Chicago, I still get to try all the tourist traps without much flack.  I had some friends in town from LA and they were craving a Chicago steak house.   The steaks were fantastic - the fillet melts in your mouth.  The rib-eye was equally good, twice baked potato - yum.  I got surf & turf and I thought the lobster tail(although quite expensive) was dry & flavlorless... I don't recommend it. The only thing I didn't enjoy about the place was how incredibly large the portions are.  Maybe it's just me, but a slice of cake shouldn't be obnoxiously large.  Don't you think it's kind of gimmicky?   Wouldn't rush back b/c of price and lack of uniqueness.... but the food is high quality

i would give this place 4 stars but they lose a star because the hostess was very rude  and our waiter did not come by to ask us for refills on our drinks or to even check on us at all....i think for the price your paying for the steaks the service should be a lot better. i dont think the overall experience was worth the final bill....to me its just another steakhouse in the goldcoast of chicago....overpriced with lousy service......

Came here for dinner with my parents after hearing a LOT of hype about it. Obviously, it's a very swanky & very famous place to eat, and it was definitely worthy of 4 stars. However, it wasn't the best steakhouse experience I've ever had in my life. There's not much I can say that hasn't already been said a thousand times before -- obviously the steak is great, obviously the food is pricey. They charge you PER SODA, which is a practice I'm considering boycotting restaurants for. Since I don't drink soda, this didn't affect me, but it affected everyone else at my table and it's ANNOYING and GREEDY to boot. But on to more pleasant things -- get the double baked potato and/or the baked sweet potato, they're both to die for. Everything we had was great, but those sides stood out. The atmosphere is fun, but obviously very very crowded. We had to wait even though we had a 9pm reservation. The attitude is definitely, "If you weren't sitting at this table, someone else would be." And, to some extent, that's justified because of their fame and the quality of their food, but that doesn't make it any more pleasant. The service was good once we were seated, but for truly great service and a truly great attitude, you should look at the next review that I'm about to write. All in all, definitely a great meal, but there are other steakhouses I'd revisit first. Like the next one that I'm going to write a review of... hint hint.

I love the diagram in the woman's apron that demonstrates how they're going to cook your steak.  Though somewhat phallic entirely too entertaining deciding how much pink you want to sink your teeth into. Started out with the Buffalo Mozzarella with fresh tomato, mushrooms, and nuts. Couldn't have had a better pairing. The seasoning was perfect, the mushrooms were not overcooked, the fresh tomato was not completely raw and everyone at the table absolutely loved this dish. Half of our party had the tomato based fish soup, and the other half had the split pea.  AMAAAAAZING split pea soup, and apparently the fish soup did not skimp on the fish nor did it let anyone down. Onto our main course.  The Fillet Mignon - medium.  Undercooked badly the first try, and with cold asparagus thank goodness the waitstaff here is great made us cut into the steak to make sure it was to our liking.  Immediately after we noticed the cow still MOOOooing on our plates the waitress took both the steak and the asparagus away and brought back exactly what we wanted.  YEAY!!! Sooo happy and sooooooo delish! Our Sides Mashed Potatoes -  You've had better but it's still great because it was exactly what you were looking for. Asparagus - aaahhh aldente... big, thick, juicy! YEEESSSS!! Spinach (lite on the oil) & Broccoli - happy the spinach was not overcooked. Some places like to leave spinach drowning for hours in boiling water and then you're left with sludge. Nice job guys! And no... unfortunately we did not have room for dessert.   Date Rating: 6 Pick up Scale: 1 Strong Suggestion: Go for the food not the crowd.  Great outdoor seating.  Glad my friend suggested this place he's obviously got great taste!

The only thing better than the food is the service.  My electric chair meal is a Gibson's twice baked potato, small filet and Turtle Macadamia pie. Worth every cent and worth waiting for if you don't get seated right away.

A Great steakhouse located in a great place on Rush street. Steak Finaminal burgers are sensational. Appatizers are very good. A little on the expensive side but it makes up for it when you eat your meal. Service is good. Recommend  to anyone for a great dinning experience

Personally, my favorite steakhouse in Chicago.  Things you must try: Great peppercorn crusted filet with bernaise, Turtle sundae that will feed 8, and the creamed spinach (just try it).  The service here is also flawless.   Being a top steakhouse in Chicago, it's obviously going to be a little on the pricey side, so save this one for that special occasion when your girlfriend is just dying to get out for a nice big steak dinner.

Wheres the beef? The midwest takes their steak very seriously... This place is no joke.  One of the best steaks I have ever had in my life.  Its alot of meat!!   Service was excellent - my waitress came and checked on me several times to ensure that everything was great (which it was!!!).  She was soo nice and even wrote down some places to check out while I was in town.  Service Counts and this place gets it!! They are serious about their steaks and their service.  A great dining experience! Definetely a must when you visit Chicago.

Do you want to know what having heaven in your mouth is like? Then run, don't walk over to Gibson's for an outstanding dining experience.  I was lucky to attend Gibson's as part of a work event so not paying = utter indulgence. Started with tasty martinis at the bar and was seated in a section with a fantastic waiter. He also worked at Second City and was hilarious!  This place provides a great dining atmosphere w/ taste. Check out all of the pictures on the walls of famous stars who have made their way through. So fun!  We started with the seafood appetizer w/ huge portions of fresh catch. I am not a seafood fan, so no personal comment here...but everyone was RAVING. I ordered the fillet with a baked potato that was bigger than my head.  The steak was amazing. Hands down the best piece of meat that has ever touched these lips. Warm, soft, so so so tasty. Melts in your mouth and requires minimal chewing. Amazing.  Dessert was a medley of several dishes including a chocolate mountain, cheesecake, and strawberry shortcake. OMG. Yum. I have a $50 gift card that I am itching to use...I cannot wait to go back!!
I had a porterhouse and damn it was good. I love how the wait staff brings out the diff slabs/cuts of beef before you order...

These are the best steaks I have ever eaten in my life. Period.  The only steaks that not only taste good but actually FEEL good in your mouth. Probably the best wait staff as well, considering each server only has like 2-3 tables. It ain't cheap, but it's worth every penny. Ever seen an 18-oz lobster tail? 48-oz portherhouse? 2-lb double baked potato? I was working so hard on my peppercorn-encrusted meal this time I was dripping sweat by the time I finished. Come to find out the air conditioner actually broke about half way through (90+ degrees outside), so our server didn't charge us for the desserts.  In the parlance of our time, Gibson's is "the shit."

There for a corporate event - private party.  They did a nice job, aimed to please.  Drinks good (could've had better gin), but steaks and carrot cake dessert was ridiculous good.  One of my co-workers did a face plant on her bike the night before and broke her hand...the staff cut her filet  mignon into tiny pieces for her.  How's that for service.  The triangle is annoying, but a good experience nonetheless.

I've lived in Chicago twice, my latest residency approaching the 4-year-mark. So how was it that I was just visiting Gibson's for the first time? I guess I always thought the place was crawling with puffed-up out-of-towners hoping to catch a glimpse of Michael Jordan or some other famous Chicagoan. And, since it's located in the heart of the Viagra Triangle, I wasn't much looking forward to running into throngs of my fellow females flirting for drinks with the older, married businessmen that permeate State and Division. I needn't have worried.  When we arrived for our 8pm reservation, the bar was so packed I didn't have to fret about rubbing elbows with any of the above. There was a great coatcheck, though, and I gladly paid the $3 to check my umbrella, coat and briefcase (who am I kidding, backpack.) I wish more places had these services, btw. I am forever carting around work and gym clothes and then heading out... We waited maybe 15 minutes before being escorted into a lively corner of the restaurants. Not only was the dining room huge, so were the tables! There were three of us, but we were surrounded by large parties, most notably some sort of bachelorette (surprisingly well-behaved) group of about 12 women. Our waiter was friendly and patient and seemed to enjoy working there. He took his time during the meat presentation where they bring out raw cuts of the different types of steak. He also showed us the large lobster tail that looked amazing, but at $100-plus, was too pricey when I was certain I'd barely have room for an entre. We shared a 4oz. portion of the spicy lobster salad to start and I can tell you right now, I will be ordering some of that to take home in the near future. Delicious sauce and really fresh lobster. For steaks, we all went with the small filet. I got mine plain, but my aunt and uncle opted for the peppered one. The one snag of the meal came when it took 3 attempts to successfully order a bottle of wine. The first two we ordered were out of stock which was frustrating, but the waiter handled it with humor and the cab blend we ended up with went well with the meal. We ordered way too many sides: creamed spinach, asparagus and fries, but they were tasty enough that I didn't feel too guilty. The cocunut creme pie was impressively built, but unremarkable in taste. All in all, this is a great place to go when you're looking for an over-the-top, excellent steak, good people-watching experience. I wouldn't mind eating that lobster salad on a weekly basis, but I'd save eating that much in one sitting for a once-a-year blowout.

I wasn't too impressed.  The place is really casual.. and the waiters wear these coats that you see meat packers in the grocery store wear.  I also don't really like my steak charred with large peppercorns randomly planted randomly.  That's their trademark apparently.  I guess I just prefer the way they make it at Morton's, Chicago Chophouse, or Ruth Chris. I do really like their desserts.. they are really big so you can definetely share.  I also think their service is good.  I spoke to the manager about how I didn't like the steak and he gave me dessert on the house.

Pretty solid steakhouse. The restaurant itself is in a good location and has a lot of space. This was the first time I'd ever been to Chicago so I'm not sure if this was typical Chicago or not, but the walls were all wood panel so it had kind of a cool, old feel too it. The steak was great, and the wait staff was good about explaining everything. I like my steaks medium rare and they cooked it perfectly (the way medium rare SHOULD be cooked). We tried some sides (the double baked potato and vegetable plate). Both were good but not spectacular. Overall I was impressed. Supposedly it's a great Chicago restaurant and I'm glad I got to go.

I had the best steak I've ever had at Gibson's.  The side dishes were also delicious although the servings are so large you need to split between 2 or 3 people. The service was excellent and very attentive.  I went on a Sunday afternoon so it wasn't crowded when I first got there although by 5 pm the bar area was packed.

gibsons.  you over cooked my steak.  dry and NOT good.  aren't you a steakhouse?  why do you suck at cooking steaks?  i know, if i wasn't happy i should have sent it back.  but someone took me there on a date and i didn't want to be rude.  so i gnawed on as much as i could and then pretended i was full.  i will never go back.

I went with some coworkers out to Gibson's earlier this week to celebrate my promotion at work.  It was a very celebratory evening and we ordered a lot of everything to pass around the table.  I was amazed to find my favorite wine on the list: a Flowers Sonoma Coast Pinot Noir.  We ended up finishing two of these in short order.  We also tried the W.R.
